title_review: One of Madrid's best restaurants but bring your wallet
review_preview: This is where the four of us spent our last night in Madrid. I must say I was left with two distinct impressions: one, the food can be unworldly or disappointing, and two, it is VERY expensive. Excellent service in an intimate setting. One dish,...
review_full: This is where the four of us spent our last night in Madrid. I must say I was left with two distinct impressions: one, the food can be unworldly or disappointing, and two, it is VERY expensive. Excellent service in an intimate setting. One dish, the butter fish, could have been the best fish dish I've ever tasted in my life. Another called knives was one of the worst. And so it went. Most dishes were enjoyable, and I can't fault the chef for putting his own spin on them. By far the majority were delicious, some sensational. But my biggest complaint of all? Asking for vino de la casa (house wine), devouring almost 2 bottles, and being charged by the glass. In an establishment with this kind of reputation, I would have expected different. Order cautiously, watch the prices, and make certain you pay for wine by the bottle and not the glass. Bon Apetit!

review_preview: I cannot fault the food - what I had was delicious.  But, I was surprised by 2 things:(i) there was one pure vegetarian option on the menu - the gazpacho(ii) and, it was 25€ for a small bowlAlthough good - I didn't...
review_full: I cannot fault the food - what I had was delicious. But, I was surprised by 2 things: (i) there was one pure vegetarian option on the menu - the gazpacho (ii) and, it was 25€ for a small bowl Although good - I didn't think it was that much better than what I make at home and certainly not worth 25€. Furthermore, I was disappointed that this was the cheapest dinner item on the small menu (the desserts were 15€). To the restaurant's credit, when we asked about veggie options, they did suggest they could prepare a plate of grilled veggies. However, I'm really getting sick of that as 'the only' off-the-menu option for vegetarians particularly when the menu (at least at Viridiana) is so interestingly varied otherwise. Otherwise, as mentioned, the menu looked really interesting for non-vegetarians and the ambiance is intimate and with nice decor and friendly English-Spanish speaking wait-staff.

title_review: Never Disappointed at this Tapas Bar
review_preview: 2014 visited again - food as wonderful as before. This tapas bar is run by a very friendly brother and sister with the back up of a great chef and waitresses. The service is fast and furious.Try the heading on the menu called "CAZUELITAS" translated...
review_full: 2014 visited again - food as wonderful as before. This tapas bar is run by a very friendly brother and sister with the back up of a great chef and waitresses. The service is fast and furious.Try the heading on the menu called "CAZUELITAS" translated as "little pots". We had the meatballs i.e. Albondigas - always enough for 2 people: also Salmarejo which is a cold soup with strips of serrano ham and grated boiled egg on the top - quite like gespacho but "better" in our opinion. The bar provides a menu in English if you are not sure what to order. It's an extremely busy bar with a terrific atmosphere. It really is worth visiting this excellent venue.

title_review: Good meal in cozy restaurant but - despite being warned beforehand - overpriced
review_preview: Made a reservation 48 hours ahead and received an e-mail confirming it and a phone call one hour before the scheduled time. Enjoyed that kind of attention. Upon arrival, we (me + wife) dismiss any aperitif and go straight for the menu. Meanwhile a small...
review_full: Made a reservation 48 hours ahead and received an e-mail confirming it and a phone call one hour before the scheduled time. Enjoyed that kind of attention. Upon arrival, we (me + wife) dismiss any aperitif and go straight for the menu. Meanwhile a small plate of excellent olives appears. As we are getting ready to order the chef shows up and sits down next to us (restaurant was mostly empty at 9.30pm, but he still did it with other people after it was full) and ran through a batch of off-menu dishes. He spoke with the certainty awarded by his experience and punctuated his remarks with snappy comments. We ended up choosing one of the starters he mentioned (an interesting take on ceviche, with mango, papaya and avocado) but stuck to the plan with the main courses. The wine was overpriced, as many commenters had mentioned on TripAdvisor. Went for a red Muga 2012 (40 euros), which was a reliable bet as Muga usually is. Though I could've sworn I had asked for a 2011 bottle. Anyway. A bit after ordering, another starter was brought to our table, a mixture of ham, gazpacho, vegetables and others. All placed side-by-side to combine as a dish. If that makes sense. We were not charged for this and it was probably the most memorable of dishes we had there - sadly, because it was either bad luck or we didn't make the right choices.  The ceviche - which we split - was refreshing, as I mentioned. And then came the main courses, both of them meat. Mine was a very elegant beef steak with marrow. Very, very low on salt and maybe a bit overcooked, but that's on me for ordering it 'medium'. The baked potatoes were a lot saltier than the meat. The wife had 'shoulder of lamb' (can't tell if this is the correct translation). It was massive. M-a-s-s-i-v-e. Tasty, but the poppy seeds really did most of the work.  We ended up ordering a panna cotta with passion fruit and coconut mousses, which was also decent. The waiter brought an added sample of another dessert, with chocolate truffles, also on the house.  We ended up paying 160 euros. Not unexpected, but also definitely exceeding what I thought was the value of that meal. We don't often go to top-rated/high-charging restaurants. We did this time because it was my wife's birthday and we were abroad. It was a great evening and we enjoyed our meal. But can't help feeling as if there was something missing. The taste: Good, but could've been a lot better. The atmosphere: Very classic, but dated. The waiters: It was the only time in Madrid I felt like I could've gotten a better treatment if I had been wearing a tie or something smarter than a polo shirt (fancy by my standards). The background music: unbearable, but perhaps mandatory?  TL;DR: good meal, as expected, but it could have and should have been cheaper and/or just better.

The freshly made olive bread followed bye complementary starters of a strawberry gazpacho and lentil stew foreshadowed the delights to come. I have stayed away from gazpacho for many years due to the safety of bland blender made tomato paste of experience however this gazpacho was divine. Followed by my lobster risotto and His hake and potatoes and deserts each I would highly recommend this establishment. The ONLY down side - minimal as it is - was a lack of serviettes to avoid gazpacho splash owe ver the service, the food and the wine choice by the staff was impeccable. Best meal in Spain yet!!

The chef, Abraham Garcia, warmly greeted me and assured me that he would prepare my "last meal in Madrid" and make it memorable. It was! It began with a complimentary small saucier of lentils with bits of lobster and only got better. The chef regales his guests with all of the many daily specials off the menu. Such a treat.Gracias, Sr. Chef!

review_preview: This was the most disappointing dining experience during our 8-day visit to Spain. The waiting service was awful. The rude, inattentive and complacent waiters ignored us completely to start with, and it took them quite a good 20 minutes to realise we were waiting for...
review_full: This was the most disappointing dining experience during our 8-day visit to Spain. The waiting service was awful. The rude, inattentive and complacent waiters ignored us completely to start with, and it took them quite a good 20 minutes to realise we were waiting for them to take our orders as they were too busy chatting to each other. We do not undertand why this place is so over-rated. Perhaps, the idea is to lure naive travellers to this place for 'canteen food' at outrageous prices. The two amuse-bouches offered at the beginning might have been a nice touch, but they were tasteless and completely over-cooked. The waiters initially forgot that we had requested no red meat for my partner when making our booking, and brought him a dish with cured ham, so we had to ask them to correct their mistake. My salad was drowning in vinegar which made it too sour to eat and the prawns wrapped in breadcrumb were so soggy that I wondered if they were safe to eat. What was advertised as the chef's signature dish (lamb tripe served with chick peas and egg) turned out to be just some kind of glorified farmer's food, which I must admit was far worse than that we had elsewhere outside Madrid. To make things worse, the desert we wanted was not available. As previously reported by one of the reviewers, the waiter who brought us the bill pointed it clearly to us that the service was not included. At that point, my partner replied that we declined to leave any tip as we really did not enjoy our meal. I definitely will caution people against this rather odd restaurant where the chef and two of his assistants went home in front of the guests and even before some of them had started their meal. I had not witnessed anything like this before.

review_preview: I had an opportunity to eat at a number of well-regarded restaurants during my short stay in Madrid, including the 2 Michelin star El Club Allard. Out of all my meals, Viridiana was by far my favorite. The first thing that stood out to me...
review_full: I had an opportunity to eat at a number of well-regarded restaurants during my short stay in Madrid, including the 2 Michelin star El Club Allard. Out of all my meals, Viridiana was by far my favorite.   The first thing that stood out to me was the warmth and attentiveness of the staff. As I only speak a little Spanish, sometimes it can be challenging to have an engaging experience with the staff of restaurants in Spain. That was not the case at Viridiana, and I found the service to be the best of my entire stay in Madrid. This comfort was enhanced by the playfulness of the restaurant. The food similarly impressed. The variety of the food made for a memorable experience. I had an opportunity to try baby eels and lamb tripe for the first time, and I was impressed with the preparation on both. The foie gras was the best I have ever had. The bitter notes that overwhelm others’ foie gras was not present and the texture was perfect. The food on the whole was very impressive and superior to everywhere else I ate during my time in Madrid.   Most importantly, the chef’s love of cooking and bringing joy through food shined through. The free appetizers provided were exceedingly generous. The chef was even kind enough to send me out a third free appetizer after I shared my love of the foie gras with the waiter. I could tell the food was made by someone whose heart is in cooking food that brings happiness. While my dinner at El Club Allard was extremely well-executed, it lacked the same focus on bringing joy to the diners that I felt at Viridiana. The food at Viridiana is clearly made with heart, and that makes for a very enjoyable dining experience.

review_preview: A very classy and elegant place and priced over the top.We were surprised by a tasty appetizer, then a small tasty soup all sent by the chef.   Then we were surprised by how large the salsa was, it would have been enough to for...
review_full: A very classy and elegant place and priced over the top. We were surprised by a tasty appetizer, then a small tasty soup all sent by the chef. Then we were surprised by how large the salsa was, it would have been enough to for two people or a meal. The prices were a bit high too, but the service was great. Then I was unpleasantly surprised that the steak was covered in a strong tasting sauce and anchovies. Ruined my steak by adding salty fish to the top. Not enjoyable. Then we did not order dessert and were surprised by a small tasty tequila infused treat that was very good.  We were also surprised by the chef coming out and explaining the entire meal to a table hosting a birthday party. Took him 15-20mins to cover it all. Then the final surprise, was the bill, not only was the prices high, but the waiter then presented a bill with the "service" line blank and make it clear that the prices did not include service. title_review: Amazing!!! Went 3 nights in a row!
review_preview: of the three nights we had in Madrid had, we 2 dinners and 1 dessert at this amazing place. The one night we had "only" dessert, we regretted not having our entire dinner there.As we summarized it during our last dinner here: amazing food,...
review_full: of the three nights we had in Madrid had, we 2 dinners and 1 dessert at this amazing place. The one night we had "only" dessert, we regretted not having our entire dinner there. As we summarized it during our last dinner here: amazing food, great prices, awesome service, cool atmosphere.  The first night we had the "menu del noche", for 12.5 euro per person, which included all together 2 starts, 2 main dishes, wine (sangria in our case), bread, and dessert! We also got 2 shots "on the house" at the end of the meal. The Leche Frita (fried milk) dessert was so good, that we came back the second night after a less magnificent dinner somewhere else. This time, the dessert, sangria and a glass of CREMA DE ORUJO (an amazing liquor, a bit like Baileys) was almost 7 euros. Again, wow. The third and last night in Madrid we knew exactly where we're going to have dinner. This evening we took the seafood platter for 30 euros, which had 4 types of shripms and lobsters and came with salad and french fries. Yummmm!!! We had other less successful meals around Madrid, and if we had to choose the best place for dining, it would be Venta El Buscon!!! No doubt about it!

review_preview: My partner and I had originally intended to book at Botin, a famously old restaurant in Madrid but unfortunately were not able to get a table until 10:30.We then found this restaurant in a top 10 Madrid book with a good write up detailing...
review_full: My partner and I had originally intended to book at Botin, a famously old restaurant in Madrid but unfortunately were not able to get a table until 10:30. We then found this restaurant in a top 10 Madrid book with a good write up detailing It would be perfect for an occasion, as it was our five year anniversary we thought brilliant! and our hotel booked us a table. Upon arrival we were shown to our table on the bottom floor of the restaurant, it was very nice and clean and had a lovely lighting to the room.  The menu was presented with a slightly minimalistic amount although we both ordered something we felt happy with.  I had the hake with mushrooms and my partner had the lobster risotto. Beforehand, an appetiser of asparagus and ham soup that we hadn't ordered appeared and the waiter said it was a speciality from the chef, although we ate it and it was very nice, I'm not sure how I feel about being charged for it as we didn't order it? As we had finished the appetiser, The Head Chef came out and spoke to diners within the restaurant. As well as our own table, there were two other couples, a group of men and a family with two small children also in the restaurant. The Chef made an effort to speak to each table, even when he approached a table that only knew English or Polish, he got the head waiter to translate for him I presume he only knew Spanish. The Chef said "Hola" to my partner and I but that was it, however every other table got a conversation. To us this was rude and dismissive of us. Not sure why he felt he didn't need to engage with us like all the others?! As my partner is a chef back home, he was confused as to why the chef wouldn't communicate with everyone, especially if he knew the waiter could translate!  My Hake with mushrooms was nice although the fish lacked in flavour, was rather bland to say the least. My partner enjoyed his dish but nothing he felt to rave home about.  We finished off with dessert, unfortunately the vanilla moose I had ordered was not available, but the waiter's did not inform me of this until at least 5+ minutes after I ordered. Instead I had pineapple sorbet and my partner had sponge pudding with chocolate sauce. Both quite plain but tasty. Some of the staff were nice, others lacking in customer service. All in all, disappointed.

review_preview: We were in Madrid for two nights immediately after Christmas, staying at the Petit Palais Savoy Alfonso. We'd been recommended a couple of restaurants but found they were closed for the holidays; TripAdvisor revealed a restaurant close by that was open: Viridiana. I didn't realise...
review_full: We were in Madrid for two nights immediately after Christmas, staying at the Petit Palais Savoy Alfonso. We'd been recommended a couple of restaurants but found they were closed for the holidays; TripAdvisor revealed a restaurant close by that was open: Viridiana. I didn't realise quite how close by till we booked by phone and made the one-minute walk.  The name appealed (I love Bunuel's film), and the decor seemed pleasingly tasteful, the mood relaxed but mercifully not loud. The food was very well cooked and presented (with some nice unexpected extras), the service attentive, helpful but not intrusive; the wine list noticeably good, mostly upmarket but still with some reasonable affordable bottles. While certainly not cheap, we felt it a sufficiently good and good-value to reserve, upon leaving, for our second night - when we had an even better dinner and an even more enjoyable experience. In particular, the Peruvian-style marinaded tuna, swordfish and sea bass was ultra delicious, and the duck cannelloni the best cannelloni I'd ever had. For tinto there is a very reasonable Sardon de Duero though it's probably worth paying a bit more for the Pesquera Crianza. I'd certainly go back when next in Madrid.

title_review: My Very Favorite Place in Madrid
review_preview: I was in Madrid for a couple weeks last year and I was really looking forward to coming back here during this visit. I love the food (the pulpo!), the atmosphere, the room, the friendliness of the patrons, and the staff. How they manage to...
review_full: I was in Madrid for a couple weeks last year and I was really looking forward to coming back here during this visit. I love the food (the pulpo!), the atmosphere, the room, the friendliness of the patrons, and the staff. How they manage to keep everything straight and everyone happy and attended to never ceases to amaze me.  You get nibbles with every drink you order and could easily get by for lunch just on the olives, cheese, chorizo and the like that would come with a few drinks. They don't repeat these freebies either. Again, how they keep tabs on all this is beyond me. The servers are obviously efficient, but they are also friendly and even a bit sassy at times, in a gentle and fun way. If you are Baja Cava, do yourself a favor and stop in, lunchtime or in the evening. I'd be shocked if you didn't walk out with a smile on your face. Oh, and it is inexpensive. What's not to love?

Tropical fruits for dessert. The meals were original, well presented and elaborated, but the greatest value is in the food quality. Incredibly fresh and tasty ingredients. Final price, including coffe: 158€

The setting is charming (movies and horses figure prominently) and the presentations are imaginative and elegant. The restaurant is just a few blocks from the Ritz and the Grand Hotel, near the Parquet de Madrid. The amuse bouche was a tomato bisque with (of all things) chopped herring and strawberries accompanied by a ginger blini topped with chourico and a poached quail egg. Amazing favors and the all really worked together. We had wonderful salads and breads before a main course of fish. Everything was exquisite lay prepared with attentive service and comfortable communications (English, Spanish, French). As noted by other reviewers, Viridiana is not inexpensive. But one leaves feeling that there was good value delivered. This is an urban stylish restaurant that knows what it's doing.

review_preview: Just spent the evening at Venta El Buscon, after having narrowed the choice down to three places for our last night in Madrid. I'm soooooo glad we chose here!! The decoration, music, staffs and atmosphere smack of true Madrid, and the food and drink are...
review_full: Just spent the evening at Venta El Buscon, after having narrowed the choice down to three places for our last night in Madrid. I'm soooooo glad we chose here!! The decoration, music, staffs and atmosphere smack of true Madrid, and the food and drink are to die for!! We had two glasses of fantastic sangria to start with whilst waiting for a table, because the place was absolutely buzzing - but not so full you couldn't move. This was so fun, and with our drinks they served the most AMAZING home-made chorizo! The friendly and efficient (and, for the most part, also English-speaking!) staff ushered us to our table in short order, and then quickly took our food and drink orders with a smile; they all seem to take genuine pleasure in their jobs! The menu was extensive, from mouth-watering tapas to full sit-down meals; we opted for a BIG PLATE OF MEATS which we had learned of from other trip-advisees (only 18EUR!). We were SO NOT SORRY BECAUSE IT WAS AWESOME!! Our food and accompanying jug of sangria arrived lightning fast, and without realising it we devoured most of our food but couldn't finish it all because there was so much! We drank and laughed, and before we knew it we had been sitting there for hours! We moved to the bar in an attempt to finish our jug of sangria (this turned out to be an impossible task), and when we asked for the bill we laughed and laughed when it came to only 33EUR for our two sangrias, our JUG of sangria, and too much food to finish! To top it off, they gave us several free nightcaps as well...we practically floated home! Best night ever; so good we almost felt stingy for only leaving a 10EUR tip! Everything was beyond our expectations and we would NEVER leave a restaurant that happy for that little money in Australia - especially in Perth, the most expensive and over-rated place for eating on the planet. We will forever have the fondest memories of our visit to Madrid, in part due to our visit to Venta El Buscon. Many thanks!

We first stumbled into here after walking through out the night looking for some where to have a light meal and enjoy some time alone with the wife. Our plan was to try a couple of places going for a walk around the area after a drink and small tapas at each place. When we stuck our head in the buscon we realised we had found some thing special with the ambience alone. Then we had the meatballs and a jug of Sangria. During this time we saw numerous dishes go by and one stood out above all. The seafood platter. We pealed our selves out of there in search of other areas to find out selves strangly drawn back to the buscon. Let me just say the seafood platter was a delight so much that my wife who dosent eat seafood was in love. The atmosphere was fun and the time special.  We have now come back the next day for the set menu. Some of the best food and value in Madrid.  Lets just say we will be back again and again.

title_review: So glad we found this great little restaurant
review_preview: This wonderful little restaurant is a real find.  It has a strong local following, a wonderful bustling and friendly atmosphere in a charming small room filled with flamenco memorabilia - in no way tacky and touristy, just bright, colourful and interesting. review_full: This wonderful little restaurant is a real find. It has a strong local following, a wonderful bustling and friendly atmosphere in a charming small room filled with flamenco memorabilia - in no way tacky and touristy, just bright, colourful and interesting. Delicious food, generous portions. The roasted peppers and anchovies and red partridge were wonderful as was the ox cheek with plums, walnuts and creamy mash....yummy! All accompanied by good wine and dessert sherry. Staff are outstanding - so helpful to non Spanish speakers and so welcoming. The best food and best value we found during our 5 night stay.

review_full: What a terrific find—merits a higher rating in our estimation. We weren’t expecting nearly as much as the restaurant delivered. It’s a relatively short and easy walk from our apartment near Plaza del Angel. The waiters, especially Jose, are incredibly gracious and welcoming—we quickly became like regulars, of which there are obviously many at the bar and tables. The restaurant draws tourists, of course, but many locals as well, and with offerings like a grilled seafood platter of gambas, langostinos, more shrimp, and others for 30 Euro, or the meat alternative of chorizo, Spanish sausage, chicken, veal, beef for 18 Euros, with platters of potatoes and peppers to accompany them, why not? Food is delivered quickly, with flair, and the dishes we had were outstanding. Flan for dessert, and if you are lucky, complimentary after dinner apertivs, so if you’re like us, you wind up eating here three nights out of your four in Madrid. Why not?

The place is rough and ready and as unpretentious as you could hope for ... but the food was very good. My wife chose the cuttle fish (sepia a la plancha) while I went for a huge plate of fried squid (calamares). I know my wife really enjoyed her cuttle fish and mine was the best calamares i've had in Spain in the past 38 years! The bottle of Conde Albarei Albarino proved to be the perfect accompaniment. We thoroughly enjoyed the evening's experience, but acknowledge that Venta el Buscon would not suit every taste.

Only point to watch is that they don't take cards - but the bill was so reasonable it was well within our cash limit.

title_review: Charming bar for tapas, beer and wine near Puerta del Sol
review_preview: With a group of colleagues we spent a couple of pleasant hours tapeando (consuming tapas) and enjoying beer in this small attractively decorated bar on one of the many narrow streets that run of Puerta del Sol. The walls are covered in colourful tiles advertising...
review_full: With a group of colleagues we spent a couple of pleasant hours tapeando (consuming tapas) and enjoying beer in this small attractively decorated bar on one of the many narrow streets that run of Puerta del Sol. The walls are covered in colourful tiles advertising beer and food. One of the walls has a Mexican-styled skeleton scene associated with Day of the Dead. The beer was called and we enjoyed gambas al ajillo (garlic prawns); a complimentary tapa of cheese and bread sticks and an excellent dish of tender squid. Prices are very reasonable and the service, while slow at times, is friendly..

title_review: Memorable tapas right near Hotel Preciados
review_preview: Found this on my TripAdvisor iPhone app when we were in Madrid in early June and wandered over there from the Hotel Preciados -- it's just a few blocks away. We didn't have a reservation but were seated without a problem upstairs. Owner/ chef sat...
review_full: Found this on my TripAdvisor iPhone app when we were in Madrid in early June and wandered over there from the Hotel Preciados -- it's just a few blocks away. We didn't have a reservation but were seated without a problem upstairs. Owner/ chef sat himself down with us and went through the menu. We had a good laugh with him about an item that was translated as goat sachets with drops of money -- it should have been "honey". In any event, that dish and everything else we had was DELICIOUS. My kids especially loved the blood sausage croquettes. We had some little pieces of tender, tasty pork over potatoes and an egg dish that was great. A great meal and fun experience.

review_preview: I've been here three times during my stay in Madrid. I was first intrigued by the very sensual tile pictures, so popped in for a coffee. The coffee was the best I've had in Madrid. Other people were obviously enjoying their breakfasts so I decided...
review_full: I've been here three times during my stay in Madrid. I was first intrigued by the very sensual tile pictures, so popped in for a coffee. The coffee was the best I've had in Madrid. Other people were obviously enjoying their breakfasts so I decided to return to sample it (I'd already eaten).  I went back today & ordered an orange juice, coffee & Spanish omelette. Coffee still great, juice freshly squeezed, & a very generous slice of absolutely delicious piping hot tortilla. This handsome breakfast cost 4.10 euros. The staff are very welcoming & speak some English but go out of their way to cater for your needs. Given that my next stop was to the Royal Academy of Fine Arts of San Fernando five minutes walk away, I returned to Melibea for lunch on my way home. I was greeted like a long lost friend. I had the dish of the day which I deduced from the limited translation was some sort of beef dish, which I was assured was delicious. It turned out to be beef cheek braised in red wine with steamed rice. Again a generous serve & it was melt in the mouth & indeed very delicious. An entree of tuna & potato salad was included, as was a pot of beer, fresh crusty bread & a choice of three desserts: mouse au chocolate, profiteroles or flan. I chose the flan which turned out to be a very agreeable creme caramel. All of this set me back a mere 7 euros! On receipt of the bill I was given a complimentary glass of a Spanish version of Baileys on ice.  I can't recommend this taverna highly enough.

review_preview: El Mollete is a very small restaurant/tapas bar close to the Opera and Royal Palace. It has a warm, friendly and authentic ambience and its clientele is made up of both tourists and locals. The menu consists of about a dozen tapas dishes and there...
review_full: El Mollete is a very small restaurant/tapas bar close to the Opera and Royal Palace. It has a warm, friendly and authentic ambience and its clientele is made up of both tourists and locals. The menu consists of about a dozen tapas dishes and there are daily specials as well. The waiters speak only a little English but take time to explain the menu and advise on the number of dishes to order. Each dish is cooked to order and brought to the table individually. The food is beautifully presented and tastes absolutely delicious. The wine is good too. I rate the two meals I ate at El Mollete as some of the best food I have ever eaten anywhere, and at an extremely reasonable price too! We paid 43 euros for 3 shared tapas dishes, bread, water, two desserts and two glasses of wine. Highly recommended! Gets busy so booking essential.

review_preview: Visiting this restaurant was like having dinner at a new friend's home. The dining area is small but so warm and inviting. The hosts were cheerful, provided amazing food and a lovely sangria. We tried the avocado salad with tuna and salmon, the huevos rotos,...
review_full: Visiting this restaurant was like having dinner at a new friend's home. The dining area is small but so warm and inviting. The hosts were cheerful, provided amazing food and a lovely sangria. We tried the avocado salad with tuna and salmon, the huevos rotos, a mushroom and shrimp risotto and the goat cheese with honey. The dishes were wonderful, bringing out the best flavor of each ingredient. We were surrounded by locals proving this is a much loved venue in the neighborhood. I would definitely return if staying in Madrid!

review_preview: Walk down a few steps into a small room with a single wooden table with four chairs, all tucked under a wooden staircase. There is a bar in the back of the room and a shelf with stools along one side. It was only 12:30...
review_full: Walk down a few steps into a small room with a single wooden table with four chairs, all tucked under a wooden staircase. There is a bar in the back of the room and a shelf with stools along one side. It was only 12:30 PM on a weekday, so there was no trouble getting a table. A young woman who spoke English brought us tapas menus in Spanish and English and told us specials for the day. She recommended 3 to 4 tapas for the four of us.  We ordered artichoke hearts with with a buttery wine sauce. Artichoke hearts are one of my favorite foods, but this blew away every other artichoke heart I had ever had. Followed by an avocado salad, which was really a smoked salmon, smoked fish, mixed green salad with some cheese. Also outstanding. Then, they brought us a mushroom risotto with tiny shrimp. I eat a lot of risotto, and this was perfectly prepared. Finally, squid with hummus crowned it all. We drank some wine and water, and crowned off the lunch with some coffee. Perfect. Besides the young woman who spoke English who helped us order, we were served by a friendly who I believe were the longtime owners. Whoever was in the kitchen was very talented. The upstairs room with 4 to 5 tables was packed by the time we left at 2:30, and bar on the first floor was full. we did not need to book at 12:30 PM, but I would do so later in the day. I highly recommend this little restaurant. I might go back tomorrow.

review_preview: Coming from Sevilla, we experienced sticker shock in Madrid, especially in our neighborhood near the palace. Saw the reviews of this place and decided to give it a try. It was just around the corner from our apartment. Small place with downstairs bar and one...
review_full: Coming from Sevilla, we experienced sticker shock in Madrid, especially in our neighborhood near the palace. Saw the reviews of this place and decided to give it a try. It was just around the corner from our apartment. Small place with downstairs bar and one table. Had to wait a bit for one of the 4-5 tables upstairs, but glad we did. The owner came up and sat down next to us to tell us the daily specials in rapid fire Madrillano Spanish. Then he repeated in rapid (heavily accented English) for the German family next to us. Place was so small, you felt like you were eating with the people next to you, but it was a fun and friendly atmosphere. Had an avocado salad, which was much more than avocados - more like a regular Spanish mixed salad with tuna, smoked salmon and a whole sliced avocado too. Calamari in GARLIC sauce was good and REALLY garlicky. Grilled rabbit and fries was really tasty, but had too many small pieces of bone. We shared with the Germans and they gave us a taste of their bacalao. Everything was delicious. Ordered a chocolate lava cake for dessert that came with a scoop of very lightly sweetened caramel ice cream. Then to top it off they gave us a couple of glasses of after dinner drinks. Wanted to come back the following night, but unfortunately they were going on vacation and going to be closed. Highly recommend this place!

title_review: Local spot for good, honest food
review_preview: This was recommended to us by our local hosts as their favorite neighborhood haunt. Very charming local  restaurant with honest, down-to-earth food. A tiny, 16-seat restaurant where the patrons are all regulars who clearly overflow with affection for the long-time restaurant staff. This is not...
review_full: This was recommended to us by our local hosts as their favorite neighborhood haunt. Very charming local restaurant with honest, down-to-earth food. A tiny, 16-seat restaurant where the patrons are all regulars who clearly overflow with affection for the long-time restaurant staff. This is not a place you go to for Instagram bragging rights (though the food is quite tasty and well-presented), but do go if you are looking for an authentic local dining experience with friendly, warm service and a relaxed atmosphere. A wonderful experience that we would repeat again and again if we return to Madrid.

review_preview: So we actually went to El Mollete tonight and had such a bad experience that I had to write about it when I got back to the hotel. So after reading lots of positive reviews online and from the NY Times we decided to give...
review_full: So we actually went to El Mollete tonight and had such a bad experience that I had to write about it when I got back to the hotel. So after reading lots of positive reviews online and from the NY Times we decided to give it a try. We went without a reservation because we had tried to call a few times and no one had picked up. When we got there (fairly early around 9 pm) there was only one table eating and we were seated at the stool area. Thinking this was because we didn't have a reservation it was fine. A few more people came in, also without reservations and were seated at tables. We thought this was kind of rude, especially since we had spoken spanish the entire time and used absolutely no english. We asked for a wine menu but there was none so we instead asked for the cheapest wine bottle. It was a fine Rioja. We orderdc the food which was okay nothing to rave about - especially after coming from Barcelona where we were blown away by the food. The rabbit was mostly bones and the mushrooms were extremely slimy giving off a gross feeling in the mouth. The calamari and pork were very good. The duck was also so-so. The best part of the meal (hint hint) comes when a waiter from the balcony drops a wine glass that hits our plate of food and shatters everywhere. The glass goes on me, my partner in the food and bread basket. Everyone gasps and tells us to watch out as another large chunk of glass almost fell on my partners neck. It fell about 7 feet which could have seriously injured us. The waiter just looks down, cleans up the glass on the floor and doesn't bother to come over. We try to get his attention in Spanish for around 20 minutes. Finally another table gets up and talks to him, he responds "someone else will deal with it". Furriated at this point I debate leaving without paying not knowing what to do. Finally he comes over and clears all the food with glass in it and the glass off the counter. No apology yet. We are talking to some patrons who apologize for the owners/waiters and we express how upset we are over this. They didn't even try to bring us a new dish or comp the food. The patrons warn the owner we are upset because of the lack of caring, especially since it was fortunate that we weren't hurt. He doesn't seem to care either just asks us if we want desert or coffee. We decline and ask for the check. We get the check and are amazed to find out the cheapest bottle of wine was 16 euros. 16 euros for a bottle that cost 3 - 4 euros in the supermarket. This is our 12th day in Spain so we have been eating out quite a lot and have NEVER, not once EVER been to a place that doesn't have a bottle of wine in the 10 euro range. We don't know what to do, it seems pointless to complain. We don't pay quick enough as he comes over looking for the money then walks away angry. I leave the bill which was 56 euros and absolutely no tip with that kind of service. As we thank the nice table for helping us he scowls at us for no tip im guessing. The nerve of this restaurant. This was honestly the worst dining experience I have ever had and urge anyone to seriously consider where they want to spend their money.

title_review: Heavenly food--this is the real thing!  Skip La Bola and head here!
review_preview: We stopped at El Mollete on the advice of the concierge at our hotel and were thrilled with our experience.  The owner, a Robert DeNiro look-a-like, was quite a character. He took us up a steep staircase into the loft dining room that had six...
review_full: We stopped at El Mollete on the advice of the concierge at our hotel and were thrilled with our experience. The owner, a Robert DeNiro look-a-like, was quite a character. He took us up a steep staircase into the loft dining room that had six tables squeezed into the space. At first, he seemed a bit peeved that we didn't speak Spanish. A patron at the next table took pity on us and tried to translate as the DeNiro character (and what a character he was) rambled off the menu at top-speed. Having no idea what to order, we told her to tell him we wanted lunch and liked everything but mayonnaise. Small plates were brought to us and each was extremely delicious: teeny-tiny grilled and marinated artichokes, thin pork medallions, marinated octopus salad, perfectly and simply prepared potatoes and for dessert, a magnificent and intensely-flavored molten chocolate lava cake. We returned the next evening for a nightcap and another round of lava cake and DeNiro greeted us like old friends. This restaurant blew us away.

We arrived prior to our 3:00pm reservation and the employee was stunned that we needed a table of two - we got seated upstairs very cozy and nice - and were told tapas on Saturday here is the choice, there was no ordering off the menu on the weekends. No problem We had a glass of white wine each and ordered two tapas. I can honestly say the service was nothing outstanding - the young lady serving was rushed off her feet. We ate, had grilled calamari and my husband had the tomato and tuna salad, drank our wine, payed the bill, there was nothing personal about the service. The bill was 32 Euros - we wouldn't rush back and certainly not walk across the city to dine again - there are many restaurants in Madrid - What a shame I was really looking forward to the experience after reading such a great travel blog but after I looked it was 18 months old.

We ordered about 4-5 dishes to share plus about 3 glasses of tinto de verano each; the bill was around 45 euro. The menu is not extensive but they had almost as many dishes on special as on the menu. Enjoyable and tasty evening.

title_review: Great food and even better value
review_preview: When our party of 8 turned up without a reservation in a restaurant that looked full we were pleasantly surprised to be shown to a table straight away. The service was great - enough attention when we needed anything without waiter constantly hovering. The staff...
review_full: When our party of 8 turned up without a reservation in a restaurant that looked full we were pleasantly surprised to be shown to a table straight away. The service was great - enough attention when we needed anything without waiter constantly hovering. The staff coped with our very poor grasp of Spanish and managed to make recommendations whic turned out to be excellent. The highlights were 2 main course shared plates for 2 (though they would have fed at least 3). The first was a range of meats which ranged from chorize and black pudding to steak and chicken. Even better was a large plate containing king prawns, langoustines,crayfish and another shellfish that I can't remember (and I do mean multiples of each). We were pleasantly surprised at the low cost of the food, but even more pleasantly surprised at the even lower cost of the drinks. I would definitely go back. Even the restauarant was busy the waiter was very happy to take group photos for us without any sign of concern. He also appeared to be genuinely concerned about whether we enjoyed the food and happy that we did. This wasn't haute cuisine, but it was great food and a great evening.

title_review: Amazing food for an adequate amount of money
review_preview: We went there just yesterday at dinner time because I had seen the reviews about this place here on Trip Advisor.We were really hungry after walking about 20km to see the city, so we went there because I'd read about the "Parrillada de Carne"...
review_full: We went there just yesterday at dinner time because I had seen the reviews about this place here on Trip Advisor. We were really hungry after walking about 20km to see the city, so we went there because I'd read about the "Parrillada de Carne" for two, which basically is a huge amount of different grilled meats, each one with its seasoning (going from barbecue sauce for the chicken, to simple grilled pork, to a mat I don't know with what tasted really similar to Indian cuisine). It was €18 for two people, which I consider a pretty fair amount. We were offered a complimentary tapa, the bread and the chupitos. Also,the glasses of sangria and beer were really generous. We paid €22, but ended up leaving €25 because we wanted to tip the really nice waiter we got. We liked it so much, we went back there again today for some tapas at lunch. We had the calamares, jamon and chorizo ibéricos and pimentos padrón, and once again we paid around €22 and left fully satisfied.

LOL .. coffee was fine and we came away with no wine or dessert for about €30.- for 2p.  next time i wiiiiiiiiiiill go to the taberna alhambra ..  thus said the locals seemed to like this place .. people were standing waiting for a table at gone 14.00 hrs .. they eat late there ..

review_preview: We chose to eat at the Viridiana largely because it was a short walk from our hotel and despite mixed reviews. We were happy we decided to eat there. The food was imaginative and tasty without being pretentious. The strawberry gaspacho with herring boded well...
review_full: We chose to eat at the Viridiana largely because it was a short walk from our hotel and despite mixed reviews. We were happy we decided to eat there. The food was imaginative and tasty without being pretentious. The strawberry gaspacho with herring boded well for what followed, as did the quality of the bread (cheese and yucca). Indeed, there seemed to be a South American touch in some of the dishes, with nopal being included in the salad. The pigeon was perfectly cooked without any imaginative flourish. They have an extensive wine list with some bottles being quite expensive. Very few half bottles, but they served decent wine by the glass. At Euro 170 for two, the bill was what we expected for such a meal. The service was pleasant and professional. If we lived in Madrid we would return.

review_preview: Viridiana was highly recommended to us by another couple.  It was an easy walk from our hotel ( the Westin Palace).  The restaurant has two floors- we ate downstairs which was a very lovely setting. The art on the walls is very interesting, and there...
review_full: Viridiana was highly recommended to us by another couple. It was an easy walk from our hotel ( the Westin Palace). The restaurant has two floors- we ate downstairs which was a very lovely setting. The art on the walls is very interesting, and there are pictures all over from the movies of Luis Bunuel. That is the good news. After we were seated, we were very thirsty from our walk. We were chagrined that a table that came in after us was waited on first, while we were ignored. Eventually the waiter came over and we placed our order. This is where things got very confused. I ordered gazapacho for a first course and fish for my main. We were first served a curry/lentil soup which was excellent, but we had not idea why we got it. Next came a barley dish with octopus. Again, we did not order this. Third came a huge bowl of gazpacho. It was very good, but should have been served in a much smaller portion. Somewhere along the way, our waiter got busy with other tables and it seemed like the bus boy took over. He was very nice, but clearly not our waiter. My main course fish dish was very good, but my husband's pork was not.  The issue that really bothered us was that there is clearly two classes of service at this restaurant. The locals/ regulars, who are frequented at their tables by the chef, seemed to have a different menu than we got. They get lots of attention. The people across from us had small cups of gazpacho, which I would have much preferred. They seemed to have a totatlly different menu. As a tourist, I felt very second class in this restaurant. I think I would recommend taking your dollars/euros elsewhere and let the locals support this restaurant.

title_review: Does not live up to its name
review_preview: We made a reservation for two in Viridiana for aour anniversary dinner. We had a table at the end in the bottom floor (I think it nicer and quiter than the first floor). The decoration is correct but a bit outdated.Service was quite good,...
review_full: We made a reservation for two in Viridiana for aour anniversary dinner. We had a table at the end in the bottom floor (I think it nicer and quiter than the first floor). The decoration is correct but a bit outdated. Service was quite good, and as it is tradional, Abraham García comes to the table to "sing" the specialities for the day. Independently of the order, there is an "invitation" as starter, including an straberry gazpacho and some vegetables and fish. It is good to know in advance, but it's really not so expensive and it tasted good (I think it was around 4,50€ per person). We ordered the eggs with truffle and boletus (good), the tataki - tiradito (which is really only tataki and, compared with good asian restaurants, was just correct) and a tuna tartar (correct, not very impressive). Good selection of breads. In general, it was good, but did not fulfill our expectations and it is a bit over priced. Around 65€ per person, (we didn't order wine or dessert)

review_preview: It is a restaurant whose best times must be deep into its past. It seems to cater to foreigners who visit Madrid for the first time and probably uses its former glory to attract them. Waiters speak English but appear totally to ignore anything about...
review_full: It is a restaurant whose best times must be deep into its past. It seems to cater to foreigners who visit Madrid for the first time and probably uses its former glory to attract them. Waiters speak English but appear totally to ignore anything about the food and wines offered by the restaurant. (I do not consider English-speaking waiters to be un unambiguous plus for a restaurant because it clearly shows restaurant's intent to razzle-dazzle its foreign clientele to the determent of having people who know something about the food.) My squid dish was just terrible. I left some 80% of it uneaten/untouched. In any "fancy", even "normal", restaurant, waiter would have reacted, offered to bring a new dish, apologized, made any comment. Nothing here, just picked up the plate. Silence. My friends’ choices were better although not excellent. The wine recommended by the waiter was the most pedestrian you can imagine. The wine card was badly organized with lots of typos and stains. The service was slow. Halfway through dinner they ran of (nice) olive-oil bread. This is a summary: you have here a very expensive restaurant that does not care whether guests like their meals or not, and runs out of bread halfway through dinner!  !

title_review: TRUST ME IF YOU LOVE FOOD
review_preview: So, I have never written a review on any of these sites...yet I check them often when traveling (which I do a lot).  I always wonder about other's reviews as I know everyone has different tastes. I am a lover of good...truly good food. It...
review_full: So, I have never written a review on any of these sites...yet I check them often when traveling (which I do a lot). I always wonder about other's reviews as I know everyone has different tastes. I am a lover of good...truly good food. It does not have to be expensive (often times the low cost meals are much better than the expensive...It just has to be excellent for what it is).  Anyhow...we were recommended Viridiana by the concierge at the hotel, looked it up online and saw that the prices were up there...but really only as a result of the crappy exchange rate with the dollar.  We ultimately made a reservation and let me say that i'm very glad we did.  It's annoying having to read a lot to find out whether a restaurant is good or not. So... In short: Awesome awesome food. One of the best tasting meals I've had in a long time. The flavors and were amazing and the presentation was fantastic . The servers were really nice in their own reserved way. Very laid back ambiance that needed some prodding to get going (I'll explain below). Cost: 217 Euros including (2 vodka martinis, 1 delicious Swedish herring special appetizer that we shared, 1 great bottle of Spanish red wine, 1 perfectly cooked and flavored grilled steak main course, 1 amazing ox-tail tamale wrapped in banana leaf, 2 spectacular desserts (mango panna cota and a chocolate custard, and 2 cups of coffee). I would recommend to any good friend.  Here's the long version.  Leaving our hotel at 10:30 pm, we hoofed it up a slight hill and found Viridiana. As we walked in to the intimate space with about 10 small 10 tables, we were hit with a furnace blast of hot air (though no one seemed to notice as most of the men were eating with their jackets on). Thinking that maybe it was us (having just walked uphill in the cold) and not them, we tried to push away the impending freak out and waited for our body temperatures to normalize.  They took our coats and sat us near the window at a really cute bench style table and poured us water immediately.  We ordered two dry vodka martinis (one dirty) and they made them perfectly. After a few minutes, we realized that it was not us and that temperature was out of control. However, crisis was easily solved after we asked the server (with broken Spanish and hand signals) if there was any way he could lower the temperature. Rather immediately, it cooled to a normal temperature.  We scanned the menu and realized that appetizers were the same price as entrees at around 30 euros, so we decided to split one and make it up on the desserts. We ordered wine and our main courses. It had begun.  We were glad we only ordered 1 appetizer and they soon brought out two small copper pots of the most delicious soup I have tasted in recent history: cream of asparagus with pancetta. They also brought us these great cheddar popover bread balls. This was in addition to the offering of rustic bread rolls with olive oil.  I was served the Swedish herring appetizer special that was beautifully presented on a bed of shaved beets, some really flavorful coulis and some frisee. It was also served with a traditional shot of iced hard alcohol. We asked for another plate so we could share,  This was about the time that I realized that it was oddly quiet in the restaurant..with the odd din of muted conversation. We asked the server if there was music and with an "Oh yes," quickly tunred to the kitchen, flipped the music switch and the ambiance immediately went from sterile to perfect with some traditional spanish guitar music.  The main courses came next. The steak was presented quite nicely. My oxtail tamale (which was not called this, but it what it was) came to the table wrapped and tied in a banana leaf that the server ostentatiously cut and unwrapped for me. It was served with a spectacular side of mole. Delicious.  We ordered to desserts from a list of 10. Both had fantastic flavor combinations of fresh fruit and berries, chocolates in various forms, vanilla and fruit coulis.  Coffee was great (hot, bold and server poured steamed milk at the table).  The service was great in every way. The timing was perfect...neither rushed nor too slow. We always had full glasses of wine, yet never realized the server filling up our glasses.  In summary, the food was amazing. If you can successfully communicate your wishes to the very friendly staff, they are more than willing to accommodate. Price (217 Euros plus 20 euro tip) was well worth the experience.

review_preview: This is not a touristy joint, but a truly family run restaurant on one of the side streets near the Opera. We were referred to this place by the reception desk at the hotel we were staying in. We had asked them for an authentic...
review_full: This is not a touristy joint, but a truly family run restaurant on one of the side streets near the Opera. We were referred to this place by the reception desk at the hotel we were staying in. We had asked them for an authentic small scale Spanish restaurant, away from any of the touristy joints. We were really glad that we were referred to this place. When we went there for lunch the only people we could see were locals including professionals. The duck and lamb dishes we had were some of the best we ever had and the Garnacha dominated wine was a perfect complement to the food. The owner of this place was very pleasant in spite of the fact that he spoke limited English. The walls of the restaurant had various pictures of people frequenting the restaurant at various times. The fact that the restaurant was founded in 1830 should make it one of the oldest restaurants in town and testifies to the quality of its food and service. Go here if you truly enjoy good food and you won't be disappointed.

I would still come back and recommend El Mollete despite unfortunate food poisoning.

title_review: Tasty, healthy tapas in cozy place
review_preview: You can eat vegetables and fish (tuna!) here if you want a healthier option than the usual meat and cheese. Intimate with tables for 12 people upstairs and a 4- top table plus bar with mostly standing room downstairs. It was relaxing dining with nice...
review_full: You can eat vegetables and fish (tuna!) here if you want a healthier option than the usual meat and cheese. Intimate with tables for 12 people upstairs and a 4- top table plus bar with mostly standing room downstairs. It was relaxing dining with nice lighting unlike some tapas places. Large portions; two tapas was plenty for the two of us to split. We enjoyed the tomatoes with thin pieces of grilled tuna--a ton of tomatoes! The grilled blue fin tuna with soy sauce over fresh spinach, topped with crispy onions included 3 big hunks of tuna. All very tasty. We also ordered a salad with lettuce,tomato, tuna, and slivered onion that wasn't particularly good; lettuce was bitter and tasted like bag lettuce. The Rioja wine by the glass was good. The cordial staff spoke limited English (and we speak limited Spanish!) but an English menu was available. Convenient central location. We recommend!

It's only a short walk from the Royal palace...so try it if you want to eat "madrid style". But book ahead! I will be going back!

review_preview: A very small restaurant with seating for 20, but if every seat was filled it would be gridlock. This owner-run establishment is near the Royal Palace, has been open since 1883, and run by the current owner for 43 years. Some reviewers have called the...
review_full: A very small restaurant with seating for 20, but if every seat was filled it would be gridlock. This owner-run establishment is near the Royal Palace, has been open since 1883, and run by the current owner for 43 years. Some reviewers have called the owner rude, but I would say brusque. He warmed up a great deal when we asked him about the restaurant, how long he had owned it, the picture with his friend, Francis Ford Coppola, and expressed interest in his recommendations for the day. His English is limited and our Spanish is poor, but we felt like old friends by the time we left. The lunch menu was all tapas, but we were interested in the menu of the day, which was prix fixe with three choices for appetizer/salad, 3 for the main, 3 for dessert and includes a beverage and cafe. We had read some recommendations to stay away from the daily menu as general advice, but we have had quite the opposite experience: it is what the typical Spaniard has for lunch and it is a very nice meal. This was definitely true at El Mollete. We started with a very nice glass of white wine, crisp, slightly sweet, and the best we had in Spain. The pour was over my shoulder, so I did not see the label, but as we were leaving I could see the Reds on offer were all premium reservas of the Rioja appellation, so I assume the white was also a premium offering. With the owner's encouragement, my wife had the salad Nicoise and I had the zucchini soup. The salad was incredibly fresh, including the tuna that was not typical canned product. The soup was fabulous. I am not quite sure what the base was, but there seemed to be a strong foundation of potato-leek with unpeeled zucchini, pepper and other spices topped off with a generous amount of truffle oil. A full bowl, and delicious to the end. The course was accompanied by a large baguette of bread, which was six large pieces of bread for the two of us. For our mains, my wife had a very nice fillet of Hake, which was broiled with butter and lemon, and I had medallions of pork loin, medium and also with a bit of Greek spices and a hint of lemon. Both were excellent and accompanied with a side of fried potato chunks that were not quite French friends, but also not quite bravas. Very good and did not make us long for catsup to add taste, which I am quite sure was not available and would have damaged our image with the owner. There is an expectation of mutual respect earned with the dining experience and a few too many clueless tourists have darkened the threshold before you. We were clueless, but self-awareness served us well. We shared a "brownie" for dessert with our espresso, which turned out to be a dense flourless chocolate cake, semi-sweet, with a side of vanilla creme sauce. Totally unexpected. Not a blue plate special, and only 11 euros apiece all inclusive. In our home city, the glass of wine would be 11 dollars. Wonderful food served with pride, a terrific deal, and a unique experience. The staff do not speak English, but they will try their best to communicate and really appreciate if you can meet them halfway. A good translation program on the phone helps, read the daily menu posted on the door on your way in, because it is not posted anywhere inside, and ask the owner about the pictures of his many friends posted on the walls. From watching the lunch service, much of the clientele are friends and regulars. We would be if we lived in Madrid.

Plus there is a cheerful ambiance that doesn't allow for grumbling. Our party of 4 folks - 2 in their 50s, 2 in their 70s - survived standing for 20 minutes by the bar while we waited for a table. And then sitting at a table that was cheek by jowl with two others. We didn't mind in the end. To start with (and continue with), there was a great rose wine to mellow our moods. Then some wonderful dishes: Grilled Padron peppers for the table and my entree, dogfish shark. Believe it or not, the shark was delicious. A meal to remember.

A gazpacho (best in the city) followed by ham and pickles with gluten free bread as muse bouche led us to our entrees. My wife had mushroom mousse with truffle and fried egg a speciality that hit the spot. I had an excellent seafood salad with a citrus sauce with a variety of green leaves. Main courses were lamb leg and calf chop with vegetables both were excellent and cooked to perfection. All accompanied with a tasty Rioja. No room for dessert. Service was very attentive especially as a table of twelve arrived shortly after us. The chef signature fedora table settings were different and appropriate.

title_review: As the Spanish would say, ¡Que Rico!

review_full: We were looking for somewhere to have dinner and I pulled up the Nww York Times' 36 hours in Madrid--I'm very glad I did, otherwise I would never have found this absolute gem of a restaurant. We made a reservation and were luckily able to reserve the last table. The restaurant looks like a little house and only has a few tables, around four on each of its two floors and a small bar area. The menu is short and simple and the place has an old-world, family-run charm. The huevos rotos were particularly outstanding, as were the sauteed artichokes which they made vegetarian. Not to be missed!

review_preview: It is a rare and wonderful moment when all the elements of a restaurant experience come together in perfect harmony.  Such a moment was my supper at Viridiana.  I had been looking forward to this meal for months and made a reservation before leaving for...
review_full: It is a rare and wonderful moment when all the elements of a restaurant experience come together in perfect harmony. Such a moment was my supper at Viridiana. I had been looking forward to this meal for months and made a reservation before leaving for Madrid. On a quiet residential street, just blocks from the Ritz, one comes upon Viridiana, a lovely little tribute to the Bunuel film and to Abraham Garcia, the chef del restaurante. And, Garcia is not just a name on the door or menu. He is everywhere; greeting, tasting, describing the menu, virtually dancing through the restaurant always focused on his guests. If you're a monolingual American like me, you may miss some of the snappy repartee but you will sense the spirit and fun in the room. If you're an English-only speaker, be sure to have Henry as your waiter. He's a true professional, fun to talk to and a real baseball aficionado. The menu is a dream and the off-menu offerings are prepared from the freshest and some of the most surprising combinations of ingredients. The house adds some lovely small courses to whatever you order that go far beyond the usual "amuse bouche." Garcia is an artist and his palette is filled with a beautiful array of flavors and textures guaranteed to delight your palate. Each course is beautifully and cleverly presented. The wine cellar provides a nice selection of wines in a wide range of prices. Service is as perfect as the food. And, Maestro Garcia is always watching. The total Viridiana dining experience is as perfect as a human experience can be. Even the presentation of the bill is unique. I can't wait to go back!

review_full: This is an opinion of Madrilenian in love with the city. One of reasons is because of places like El Mollete. This tiny bar -where you can both stop for a quick beer or have a romantic dinner- is a modern version of what we call tasca: small restaurant where traditional homemade food is served. Normally, they have devoted clients that repeat oftenly.  Well, at Mollete you'll find the old-fashioned tasca experience with a smart touch. Great food, great wine, fine service. Great place to feel like a madrilenian.

title_review: Tomas and Ursula make El Mollete a place to come back to again and again!
review_preview: I am here in Madrid for nearly 7 weeks on business, and a friend who lives here told me that we *must* stop in to have a little something one evening.    We went (a bit early, which was good because we did not have a...
review_full: I am here in Madrid for nearly 7 weeks on business, and a friend who lives here told me that we *must* stop in to have a little something one evening. We went (a bit early, which was good because we did not have a reservation and the place is quite small), four of us, and were seated immediately. We ended up just having them bring what they had... which was amazing. The plating wasn't fancy, but it wasn't the decor or the jazzy presentation that made me want to come back. It was the atmosphere and the FOOD. Comfort food is a very good way to describe this.   Every little morsel was positively delectable. We started with some roasted peppers with a balsamic reduction and "Philadelphia" (that company must be thrilled that any time someone needs to refer to cream cheese in Europe, it's with their name... ).. simple and delicious.  Next we had some amazing artichoke hearts with creme de fois. So tender that I nearly needed a spoon!  After this came the morcilla. Now, I will admit. I am a morcilla addict.. if there were meetings for this particular disorder, I would be at all of them, happily. However. These came in thick slices, surrounded by filo pastry, and drizzled with local honey. Simple, but *inasanely* delicious.  I believe the next plate was the croquetas.. shrimp and cod. Yes, please. These can differ all over the city, but Ursula's were creamy and perfect.  Then a plate of hand cut fries with the eggs. I don't know what they feed Spanish chickens so that they produce such delicious eggs? .. but please, Spain.. keep it up.  Finally (yes, the four of us managed to handle all this food, and slept like rocks afterward.. ) came a "little chicken"- roasted and gorgeously juicy, stuffed with rice and dried fruit and what seemed like a bit of liver (awesome), over a few more fries with some lovely juicy gravy.  We had a lovely bottle of dessert wine (they have a great wine selection), and then split two desserts between us.. a chocolate lava-ey gooey insane item, and a lovely lighter vanilla-ey cheesecakey cake.  All this, including the Tinto de Verano we were all drinking before we began and throughout the meal, set us back around 20 euros each. A bargain at half the price, and I'm not embarrassed to say that we stopped in again the following night.... and have a reservation for this evening as well ;)  I haven't been for lunch, but am told by my friend that you can have a great lunch for around 10 euros.  Stop in and give El Mollete a try!

review_full: Similar to the other reviews, I found El Mollete from the NY Times article. I'm American and my husband is Spanish; I've been living in Spain for the past couple of years. Based on amazing food experiences throughout the country, I would contest the high rating given by other reviewers. We had the octopus (pulpo) - of good portion and quality; ox (buey) -- large portion (relative to Spain) served with french fries, served rare (a plus for us), quality disappointing/mediocre, grisly; and fried eggs (huevos revueltos - typical in Madrid) -- sunny side up egg over a bowl of fresh french fries, rich and heavy, would have been an ideal meal in my college years after a night out. The restaurant itself was small, charming, and situated on a quieter street (went on a Tuesday in October and was full). It seemed like the menu almost had a flat rate per plate as most plates were 10 euro. Service was good/normal. All in all, fine experience: nothing to complain about, nothing to rave about either.

title_review: Favourite in Spain for both food and service
review_preview: This little place is easily missed as it's on a quiet street off the main drag, near the theatres.  Everything we ordered from the menu were, in our opinion, the best sort of experience we look for - brininging together fresh ingredients in interesting and...
review_full: This little place is easily missed as it's on a quiet street off the main drag, near the theatres. Everything we ordered from the menu were, in our opinion, the best sort of experience we look for - brininging together fresh ingredients in interesting and palate titillating ways. Nothing arrogant or pretentious, just great combinations that work. An example is the morcilla that came wrapped in a thin filo casing, fried and dressed in honey. Or soft, melt in your mouth artichokes covered in melting foie. There's a usual menu (helpfully translated into English on a facing page) and the daily specials, which you'd need some Spanish to understand. On our first visit, we didnt make any reservation and the waiter stood studying for a long time his table set-up trying his darnest to fit us in because we had arrived very early and waited patiently for the kitchen to open. On our 2nd visit, the two waiters, one of them the owner, recognized us and shook our hands as he walked in. For two obviously non-Spanish who have been feeling super out of place at every tapas bar we ate yet, this was a gesture that made us feel so welcomed. Place is small. Reservations recommended, but bar works fine too. Kitchen opens at 9 but do arrive by 8 to grab a comfortable spot at the counter to eat at.

title_review: 7 table restaurant and the most authentic home cook Spanish meal
review_preview: We discover this tapas place by chance and what a discovery it was. It is a former tavern which according to legend was once owned by Luis Candelas, Madrid's most famous bandit, who sold it to his close friend who is a baker by the...
review_full: We discover this tapas place by chance and what a discovery it was. It is a former tavern which according to legend was once owned by Luis Candelas, Madrid's most famous bandit, who sold it to his close friend who is a baker by the name of Mollet. Therefore, in all bandillero tradition, Luis Candelas gave his friend a bandit's nickname "El Mollete" which later became the name of this place. This tiny atmospheric restaurant of only two floors is all wood beams with brick-stone walls centuries old. However the food is the main attraction as this is one of the best (if not the best) home cook tapas in Madrid at very reasonable prices. Everything on the menu is good (except only perhaps the house wine). However because it's so famous and yet so humble (this is not a restaurant with pretentious airs) most of its tables are always full. So if you fancy a sit down tapas-dinner, do call to book or show up punctually on time at 9 pm. any later than 9.30 pm means you will have to stick to the bar.  There is a brief English menu translation from the Spanish menu but if you know Spanish, then it's easier (and recommendable) to try the house's daily specials which the waiter will recite for you.

review_preview: We read about El Mollete in the New York Times, and wanted to try it based on their recommendation. They said that reservations were a must since it is an extremely small place. That is correct... There are a couple of tables downstairs, and about...
review_full: We read about El Mollete in the New York Times, and wanted to try it based on their recommendation. They said that reservations were a must since it is an extremely small place. That is correct... There are a couple of tables downstairs, and about 4 tables upstairs. Very small, very intimate. We just asked to have some food brought out to us, and though I'm not quite sure what we ate, it was all delicious! The cold soup was a garlicky creation, and the other small plates we had were equally yummy.  The restaurant is located on a small street near the Opera house, and if we weren't looking for it, we never would have found it! It is definitely worth finding, but make a reservation first.

title_review: Great little spot with yummy food and a friendly owner
review_preview: We went here on our first night in Madrid.  We easily walked from our hotel which was just the other side of the Plaza de Espana.  We requested a 10:00 table but were told we could do 9:00.  Of course when we turned up at...
review_full: We went here on our first night in Madrid. We easily walked from our hotel which was just the other side of the Plaza de Espana.  We requested a 10:00 table but were told we could do 9:00. Of course when we turned up at 9:00 we were the only people there (as we suspected). So we had a quiet hour to enjoy the personal service of the owner and sample all the yummy dishes he suggested. The place is cozy and attractive. Its a red checker tablecloth type place but the walls and floor are exposed stone and that is pretty cool. There are two levels and both are fairly small so its an intimate spot. We had about 6 different plates that the friendly owner suggested and delivered and they were each delicious with only one exception and in fact it was the one thing he had not suggested. It was the squid and it was kind of gross. Way over salted and a bit "soft" and cold. We had 2 bottles of the house white wine which was obviously nice or we would not have had two bottles...and the bill came to 75 euros! We were pleasantly shocked. By the time we left around 10:45 the place was rocking with what appreared to be mostly locals as the owner was greeting many of them like long lost friends. The place is on a very quiet little street and is easy to miss. But if you want a delicious and good value meal in a laid back setting- don't miss it. If you want to be part of the crowd I would advise you insist on a table after 10!!

title_review: Confused - this restaurant didn’t have Japanese options last night
review_preview: So bizarre - the menu must have changed because the only ‘Japanese’ option was the sauce on the salmon dish. Other than that I wouldn’t consider Wellies AT ALL a Japanese restaurant. Actually I would say it had more Italian-like dishes...The only thing that’s...
review_full: So bizarre - the menu must have changed because the only ‘Japanese’ option was the sauce on the salmon dish. Other than that I wouldn’t consider Wellies AT ALL a Japanese restaurant. Actually I would say it had more Italian-like dishes... The only thing that’s the same from some of the reviews is a) quite expensive b) service kind of lame c) they do nickel and dime you on EVERYTHING and d) food fairly good after getting our order right.  I’m giving them two stars because of two reasons - My daughter’s Chicken Milanese was totally RAW. Not just pink- 100% raw. She took a few bites it knowing & then we called the waitstaff over - not so much as an apology. S a matter of fact they kind of acted like it was an imposition to have to COOK her chicken. We thought maybe they’d consider giving us something for the grossness but not even a comment about it.  Then we got the bill & they had a charge of course for the raw chicken fiasco, for the bowl of olives we didn’t ask for AND a charge for the three individual pieces of bread THEY OFFERED.. Even had the audacity to list the chefs taster at the beginning with ‘ no charge’ like we should be soooooooooooooo lucky to not have to pay for something we didn’t ask for in the first place. Other reviewers mentioned the same thing - whatever, we had to pay extra for all of these items and we’ll live, but it sure leaves a terrible taste in your mouth when you feel like you’re getting screwed. That’s ok, now we know!

review_preview: Pepote the owner is the front of the house will be the one serving you, and he is also the chef. Don’t know how he does it, and graciously too.  Every dish was delicious and made in house.  Pepote loves what he is doing and...
review_full: Pepote the owner is the front of the house will be the one serving you, and he is also the chef. Don’t know how he does it, and graciously too. Every dish was delicious and made in house. Pepote loves what he is doing and it shows in the taste of the food that you enjoy. We started with a shrimp appetizer to share, that had oil, mayonnaise, herbs, bits of pickle? The large shrimp were tender and delicious and the sauce was so good we could have sopped it all up with our nice warm bread. But we resisted. We each had on his recommendation a spiced lamb dish and a chicken dish. Both slow cooked with vegetables, each like a stew but the flavours were still bright and clean. We finished by sharing a thin cake square with fresh cream in the middle and a fruit glaze on the top. We would definitely come back if we could. We think that for food cooked from scratch with skill, this is very good dining value.
