title_review: 4 star food with 5 star value, price and service
review_preview: You will have a good meal for a very good price. Portions are generous. Albeit, it is not food you would necessarily rave about.The mixed paella was tasty with a fairly good amount of seafood. But it is cooked in a large batch and...
review_full: You will have a good meal for a very good price. Portions are generous. Albeit, it is not food you would necessarily rave about. The mixed paella was tasty with a fairly good amount of seafood. But it is cooked in a large batch and is served to you quickly when you order. So it is missing some of the crusty flavor of paella cooked individually in a pan. We also had the mixed grill of meats. Most were good except that the chorizo was extremely salty, and the pork belly was extremely chewy that we did not eat most of it. But chicken was soft and tasty. Ribs were good too. We also ordered some additional pork ribs. The meat itself was tasty but it is cooked quickly with sauce lathered on. It does not fall off the bone like we expect ribs to be in the U.S.  All in all, good value for a hearty meal without big budget. 4 of us eat well for less than €40.

title_review: Venta El Buscon es muy bueno
review_preview: We came across this tapas restaurant on the final leg of our trip and it was a great place to relax and soak up the local flavor of Madrid. We liked it so much that we ended up coming out a second time on our...
review_full: We came across this tapas restaurant on the final leg of our trip and it was a great place to relax and soak up the local flavor of Madrid. We liked it so much that we ended up coming out a second time on our final night in Spain, making it the only place we visited multiple times, excluding gelaterias in Florence. The first night we had grilled squid, grilled vegetables and chicken wings with house Sangria and beers. The second meal included grilled meats, salad, fried peppers, wild mushrooms and fried potato and paella. The grilled meats included chicken, pork ribs, veal strip steak, black pudding and red paprika sausages.Enough to make any carnivore ecstatic. Our waiter Tierno was very entertaining, trying out Korean phrases on my wife. The Sangria was a house mix that included Malibu and vermouth, creating a flavorful drink. I can honestly recommend this restaurant.

review_preview: ... I wanted to give it a try to this restaurant after reading so much about it.So just after worked, I came straight here to the restaurant to get my dinner .I strongly suggest to book well in advanced even though the orders...
review_full: ... I wanted to give it a try to this restaurant after reading so much about it. So just after worked, I came straight here to the restaurant to get my dinner . I strongly suggest to book well in advanced even though the orders go fast and there's a pretty fast reshuffle of tables . The venue is great. Being in the centre of Madrid with only few steps from "plaza Del sol " already gives a good atmosphere of the place and puts you in a good mood.  This is indeed a Good old restaurant and it's cute the idea of those two pictures of the memorable ancient characters painted on the walls with their background faded away giving an extra touch of an old tavern letting you think of the times of the thousand meals consumed here across centuries. It almost gave me the goosebumps .  So I was then ready for my order . Three plates out of the menu and the waitress, kind and nice, went against his interest by suggesting to reducing the selections because my portions were going to be big and very generous.  Well, I tried my luck and I sticked to my choices and went anyway for salty grilled green peppers, Deep fried spicy chilly shrimps and potatoes and meat croquettes along a couple of local beers, so called "canas". Well, it was all delicious . Served quickly to the table . Food was tasty and indeed each single plate was very generous.  All of the above was not that expensive after all . Paying 26€ for a full tasty meal in a characteristic restaurant in the heart of Madrid wasn't bad at all.  I suggest you all to give it a try . Ciao Epi

Although we explained that we didn't eat meat, an amuse buche of Iberian ham was served, then a creamy soup. I left the meat and ate a spoonful of the soup, immediately feeling sick. I don't know if it was cream or butter or what was in the soup, but the waiter sneered at me for not eating what the chef determined I should eat. I couldn't eat the rubbery octopus or most of the sashimi, and again, the waiter looked at my uneaten food and shook his head as if I were a bad child. He was unhappy we didn't want dessert, which I couldn't eat because of dietary restrictions, and my stomach was very upset from whatever was in the soup, so I had to rush out. The worst indigestion I've ever had. Of course, I have no idea what the meat and cheese are like. Maybe they're delicious, but I'll never known.

title_review: Consistently excellent food and price point.
review_preview: I reviewed La Puebla last year during our trip to Spain and have to write another. This restaurant alone made our decision to return to Madrid an easy one. Consistently delicious food. Always fresh. The owner, Ramiro and his two sons run the floor and...
review_full: I reviewed La Puebla last year during our trip to Spain and have to write another. This restaurant alone made our decision to return to Madrid an easy one. Consistently delicious food. Always fresh. The owner, Ramiro and his two sons run the floor and his wife runs the kitchen. Well, there are so many things to talk about that I plan to keep you all in suspense.  They have a fixed price for lunch, 12.50 euros, (1-4:30, Monday to Sunday) For this price you get wine, first plate, second plate and desert. Real bargain. We have yet to find a place with this price point, selection, and overall experience.  What I will tell you is that certain days of the week they offer a certain specialty dish. E.g., Thursday and Sunday, they offer paella valenciana. Monday is roast lamb day. Etc. Too much offered to write it all down. Know that we ate their 4 times this week and each time left in awe. Can’t wait for Monday so I can have the lamb dish. Must stop if you want real Spanish cuisine. Happy eats.

review_preview: Impossible to beat this for quality of food and value combined. It is a simple, old stlye, unpretentious restaurant. Asides from the basic decor, I cannot find one single thing to fault. The choice of dishes on the fixed menu is as good as most...
review_full: Impossible to beat this for quality of food and value combined. It is a simple, old stlye, unpretentious restaurant. Asides from the basic decor, I cannot find one single thing to fault. The choice of dishes on the fixed menu is as good as most a la carte restaurants. 8 or ten options in each section. Home made, traditional, simple Spanish recipes. The portions are very large, so go to the restaurant with a good appetite. We had, mushrooms and sausage for starter, spaghetti, posto with egg(my favourite) and tempura eggplant. All very tasty. For mains we had veal, steak, and seabass. The deserts, which are normally a letter down on a fixed menu, were really good. Not fancy or elaborate, but homely and wholesome, apple cake, and Santiago cake, delicious custard (natillas), stewed pear in wine... All for 15 euro a head! Incredibile. Highly recommended.

review_preview: We booked this restaurant on the basis of the reviews and were very disappointed. The atmosphere was quite flat and the air temperature unbearably hot in the basement.The waiter was offhand and condescending and seemed to feel he was doing us a favour.The...
review_full: We booked this restaurant on the basis of the reviews and were very disappointed. The atmosphere was quite flat and the air temperature unbearably hot in the basement. The waiter was offhand and condescending and seemed to feel he was doing us a favour. The starters/amuse Bouche were tasty but very large affecting our appetite for the main course. One of our party ordered lamb shoulder. It was meant to be slow roasted but seemed to have been boiled and was devoid of all flavour and the texture was rubbery. The saffron couscous was grey and unappetising and tasteless. When our friends dissatisfaction was politely raised it took several attempts to persuade the waiter to speak to the chef. The waiter had to be asked about the response and he simply shrugged and said the chef said it was a matter of taste. We left feeling that our evening had been really disappointing...not just as a result of  Mediocre food but mainly the lack of gracious response from the staff. The cost was not insignificant compared to other more modest but good quality restaurants in Madrid. This restaurant is not to be recommended and needs to look closely at its service attitudes and the quality of the food they provide.

The owner and our waiter spoke some English and did not mind my attempts at Spanish. Luckily my wife is fluent, which helped as they didn't have an English menu. That being said you Can't point to anything and be assured you will get great food. We are in Madrid only four days and we plan to go back before we leave. Can't recommend it enough.

title_review: Ate woderful food with the locals
review_preview: My wife and I were strolling through old town Madrid and saw the Trip Advisor sign in the window of a nice looking local restaurant.  Out front was a sign that had a "Menu del Dia" for 14.75 Euros (including all taxes) that had a...
review_full: My wife and I were strolling through old town Madrid and saw the Trip Advisor sign in the window of a nice looking local restaurant. Out front was a sign that had a "Menu del Dia" for 14.75 Euros (including all taxes) that had a large number of choices on the menu. We went inside where there were several tables with white linen tablecloths and were greeted by a very friendly waiter. We knew it was a restaurant that catered to locals since nobody spoke English, and none of the other diners looked like tourists like us. But the staff were very helpful and considerate. In addition to the menu items we were served a bowl of olives and a basket of bread. The menu consisted of a starter, a main course, a dessert and drink. My wife had a half bottle of very good Spanish red wine. I had the local beer, which was also very good. I opted for the Paella Valencia, which was a seafood/chicken/rice dish, which was wonderful. My wife had the Castilian (ham) soup which was also very good. Next I had the Rabbit with Garlic and my wife had the grilled lamb chops. Both were very good and came with fried potatoes. For dessert, I had the Tarta de Queso con Arandanos (blueberry cheesecake) and had a side of homemade vanilla ice cream with raspberry sauce. It was awesome. My wife had the homemade Flan with whipped cream and carmel sauce. The whipped cream was the best we ever had. At the end of the meal when they brought our check (total of 29.50) they gave us two aperitif's. One was something that cold Bailey's which they said was for my wife and she said was awesome. Mine was a yellow liquid that tasted similar to lemoncello. It was equally good. All-in-all, this was a great dining experience and I would heartily recommend it to anyone.

title_review: A great find on a great street -  Amazing tapas - A must visit place!
review_preview: We returned to this street after visiting other tapas bars and found it to be superb. Within the city but quiet enough to be off a tourist trail.On the last day we visited and had our final tapas meal. Probably one of the best...
review_full: We returned to this street after visiting other tapas bars and found it to be superb. Within the city but quiet enough to be off a tourist trail. On the last day we visited and had our final tapas meal. Probably one of the best of our few days in Madrid! We did the Spanish thing and sat at the bar, went for a couple of drinks, red wine and a beer, our accompanying “tapa” consisted of some amazing oven baked chicken wings. Having looked at the menu we then ordered some “Patatas con trez bravas” Potatoes with 3 sauces –cheese alioli and spicy tomato, & some “Croquettas” which were ham and cheese, we got a basket of bread as well. More drinks and the whole lot came to not much! Around £10 I recall. Food quality was superb, perfecto in fact. Id say of the dozen or so establishments we visited, this was up there at the top. Service was great, we tried our best Spanish, the interior and décor was also superb, place really filled up after we had arrived around 2pm or so. Some of the food coming out looked amazing, they do a paella for 1 served in its own mini paella dish. My only regret is that it was our last day and we couldn’t return. Full of Spanish, a real great atmosphere and great value. If I go back to Madrid I will be sure to call in, together with visits to the other 2 tapas bars I also visited on the same street! JUMP IN!

I walked in to an empty restaurant with my friend - we were seated immediatelly and the staff quickly helped us with the menu, recommended and explained everything (even got the chef out of the kitchen to tell us about the food!). A three course meal (starter, second and dessert, with bread and wine/beer/sangria/soft drinks) go for €12 per person - excellent food quality, really cheap restaurant, very nice atmosphere! This is where the locals go - not a single tourist (besides me and my friend) came here during my stay, which is unfortunate, since this is an excellent restaurant! Highly recommended!

title_review: The absolute best value for your money
review_preview: I first came to La Puebla restaurant in 1987, while I was on a sabbatical leave. The food then, as now, was straight forward. This is home cooking (comida casera) at its best. Portions are generous and what you see on the menu is exactly...
review_full: I first came to La Puebla restaurant in 1987, while I was on a sabbatical leave. The food then, as now, was straight forward. This is home cooking (comida casera) at its best. Portions are generous and what you see on the menu is exactly what you get: no fancy sauces, no pretty little add-ons. Instead, you get well-cooked simple food that is delicious and incredibly inexpensive. For value and insight into Spanish home life of the 1950s, you can't beat La Puebla. Please keep this a secret.

review_preview: La Vaca y la Huerta is a Steak Lovers Paradise!!! Nice wood long tables, clean white ambiatic decor and a bar you can slide right up to. But the real joy is the Cold Glass Case filled with your choice of steaks. Serious cuts of...
review_full: La Vaca y la Huerta is a Steak Lovers Paradise!!! Nice wood long tables, clean white ambiatic decor and a bar you can slide right up to. But the real joy is the Cold Glass Case filled with your choice of steaks. Serious cuts of aged Spanish Beef - take your pick and let me tell you they are grilled to perfection. We did a 1 kilo Ribeye done to a barely rare and it was every bit as amazing as you could hope for. Rubbed with Mediterranean Rock Salt and just a touch of pepper and this was heaven. If you're looking for serious joy in Salamanca - La Vaca y la Huerta will fill you up and keep you coming back for more!!! Gracias amigos - the service is as great as the food. Excellent wine and beer selection as well as plenty of dishes to choose from, but really, do the right thing, get a steak, you'll be happy you did.

title_review: This is what makes a day perfect!
review_preview: I came here with 5 friends, mostly because off the many positive reviews on Tripadvisor, and we all loved it.In fact we started our weekend here but also came back on the last day, cause we wanted to end our journey here!Whenever you...
review_full: I came here with 5 friends, mostly because off the many positive reviews on Tripadvisor, and we all loved it. In fact we started our weekend here but also came back on the last day, cause we wanted to end our journey here! Whenever you are looking for a typical place to have lunch/no nonsense food or tapas in Madrid, with 'the real atmosphere' and correct prices, just go to this awesome place and enjoy. For those looking for gastronomic extravaganza and molecular fantasies, please do not enter ... Here waiters are joyful and it feels like being amongst friends that you know for years... Food is typical and authentic, in both taste and presentation. Decoration is magnificent and warm, and history is present... Even the menu in Art-Deco style adds up to the harmony of this nice little gem. And then there is the Spanish 'Cocina' with a nice choice of meat-and fish dishes, and tapas of course. We followed advice and had the 'Menu del dia' ( 3 course lunch, bread, one drink and some tapas for starters), added some bottles of wine (3, 4, last day may be 5?) and after ab. 3-4hrs we left. Oh yes, the bill... Less than €90 on both ocassions!!!

review_preview: Well worth a visit to the "Cow and the Harvest" should you be in Madrid.  The menu has several choices, with menus from €10.  It was very busy during lunch so may be a good idea to reserve.  I am still dreaming about the tomato...
review_full: Well worth a visit to the "Cow and the Harvest" should you be in Madrid. The menu has several choices, with menus from €10. It was very busy during lunch so may be a good idea to reserve.  I am still dreaming about the tomato slices we had as an appetizer. Amazing that just a simple slice of beef tomato with olive oil and salt could taste so good.  I choose the "low calorie" menu and had mussels with a tomato sauce and a hamburger. Note that the hamburgers are served rare in the middle here, which some people might not be used to. Desert was some fresh pineapple. For vegetarians there are plenty of options.  I would definitely come back here. The food is simple, no fuss and really good with the emphasis on quality rather than quantity.

title_review: Wonderful Chinese Dinner. Hakao is a MUST!
review_preview: This is a charming restaurant serving genuine Chinese dishes served by a crew of friendly and diligent waiters/waitress. We got the Hakao, XLB and mapo tofu. The Hakao were absolutely fantastic. Probably the best ones I got since my last trip to HK. The XLB...
review_full: This is a charming restaurant serving genuine Chinese dishes served by a crew of friendly and diligent waiters/waitress. We got the Hakao, XLB and mapo tofu. The Hakao were absolutely fantastic. Probably the best ones I got since my last trip to HK. The XLB were also good, but the taste was too similar to regular pork giozas (plus there was not much soup inside). The mapu tofu, genuine and tasty, although I think they should remove the Sichuan pepper flowers from the sauce (I actually love the flavor and the fragance of these peppers, but putting one of them into your mouth is "too much"). Decent prices (not cheap, not expensive), great atmosphere and decoration and, as I said, friendly (although a bit slow) service. I'll be back!!!

Anyhow - I totally recommend this place.

title_review: Delicious food in a very warm and inviting restaurant.
review_preview: We visited Shanghai Mama for lunch today without a reservation and they were very booked up but managed to squeeze us in for an hour. My partner and I live in Asia and after a few weeks in Europe we were craving some Asian cuisine....
review_full: We visited Shanghai Mama for lunch today without a reservation and they were very booked up but managed to squeeze us in for an hour. My partner and I live in Asia and after a few weeks in Europe we were craving some Asian cuisine. Shanghai Mama's did not disappoint, we had the meat dumplings, pork balls, crispy duck and special fried rice. All of the food had incredible flavour, and varied ingredients and the meal was absolutely delicious. The staff and service was very friendly and efficient and we did not have to wait long, although if we had it would have been worth it anyway. I highly recommend this restaurant and we hope to return in the future.

title_review: Sweet place to hang and enjoy
review_preview: So my buddy and I got the scoop from the fella at the front desk, we wandered across the street around four PM and wandered back to our hotel around nine ?!!?  Yeah, that much fun, it took us four hours’ish to enjoy three bottles...
review_full: So my buddy and I got the scoop from the fella at the front desk, we wandered across the street around four PM and wandered back to our hotel around nine ?!!? Yeah, that much fun, it took us four hours’ish to enjoy three bottles of wine along with sharing several of his, the owners, dishes. He cooks with passion, is a good conversationalist, and enjoys those little stoogies that Clint Eastwood would smoke in those SpaghettiWesterns...The irony, a chef with a cigar habit ??? First plate was scrimp in an olive oil and sort of mayo crepe sauce. Served cold it was delic’ and I think I’ll try to duplicate it on arrival home. Then we chatted for twenty or so minutes, then a hot cod dish where the fish was flaked into a tomato sauce with red peppers and onions and a smidgen of garlic. Tasty. The another twenty or thirty minutes and we finished with a calamari dish done in ink, along side a small side of rice. This place is off in a residential area, so the folks there are locals. If you are around it know that you’ll enjoy it. All the Best, Salida1048

review_preview: Don't bring your little kids. review_full: Don't bring your little kids. This is a World-class dinning experience. Award winning Chef, Abraham García, will dazzle your taste buds with his imaginative presentations and gastro-techniques. García started in the kitchens of Madrid at age 13 and has been perfecting his take on food preperation for over 4 decades. His secret for success: "Technique, memory and skill". These skills extend to exploring local markets for the freshest ingredients which show up on his seasonal menu. This is seafood at its best. Prime meats cooked to perfection. And surprises with every course. (Try his gaspacho with strawberries and herring.) Don't go alone, because no one will believe you.

Food was a bit mixed--nice ham, great bread, but tasteless tortilla. There was a real buzz in the place and it was busy without being too jammed. Seemed to have a mix of locals and tourists. While the food wasn't fantastic, I'd go back because we had an enjoyable time there.  We also laughed when we saw their breakfast sign outside that offered various breakfasts with your choice of "coffee, tea, or beer!"

review_full: Read these great reviews on the Tripadvisor website so decided to book a table as a birthday treat for my husband. At the end of the evening, I must admit I was a little disappointed...We were one of the first to arrive around 8.30pm (Mon evening) and were asked whether we wanted to sit upstairs or downstairs...I chose upstairs but after visiting the toilets which were downstairs, I would recommend readers to sit downstairs as it is much cosier. The amuse-bouche and starter were very nice...very interesting flavour combinations and I thought- yes we are in for a treat! Unfortunately the main course and dessert let us down a bit. It was nice but not more than that. Apart from the amuse-bouche, I felt the presentation of the food could be updated. On the other hand, the staff were very friendly and offered us a second glass of Spanish liqueur for free, which was a very nice gesture. Anyway, to conclude...nice food but despite some raving reviews, don't expect anything more than that. We paid 210 euros for 2 three course meals, a bottle of wine, 2 glasses of cava and 2 liqueurs.

review_preview: Given the relatively mixed reviews I was not sure what to expect at this restaurant. In the end, I was disappointed - I think 3.5 out of 5 would be my more accurate rating.The menu offered a good choice that looked enticing however my...
review_full: Given the relatively mixed reviews I was not sure what to expect at this restaurant. In the end, I was disappointed - I think 3.5 out of 5 would be my more accurate rating. The menu offered a good choice that looked enticing however my choices did not really deliver. In both cases the dishes were overwhelmed by strong flavours that did not work with others on the plate. I started with duck fois gras, and the orange marmalade was the dominant flavour on the plate. I followed that with guinea fowl which was accompanied by a very rich sauce. The other point of note was that the amuses bouches were very large - and ultimately dampened our appetites. The gazpacho we were served first was a particularly large bowl! The wine list was good, and service was efficient. Our bill came to about 250 EUR for two, including a decent bottle of wine and coffee. I think this is a decent restaurant but I cannot believe it is one of the best in Madrid and I am sure others are worth visiting ahead of it.

An incredible 2.5 hour dining experience on their small street side outdoor dining area. Staff was extremely friendly with decent English language skills. We started with the peach Bellini which was fantastic. In addition we ate… two amuse-bouche (although more technically “free appetizers” as they were much more than bite size); gazpacho; lentil stew with prawns; pork meat balls with red curry, cus-cus and roasted peach; beef tenderloin on corn talo with soften molten goat cheese; a bottle of the 2009 Abadia Retuerta Pago Negralada Tempranillo, and Crème brûlée with espresso for desert. Every dish was excellent, overall our best meal in Madrid. The décor was pleasant with creative touches related to the movie the restaurant takes its name from. My wife is gluten-free, no challenges for her.

title_review: A gem not to be missed
review_preview: I was fortunate enough to be staying around the corner and it was the closest place. There are so many mediocre places to eat in Madrid, I was happy to have been this lucky. This place immediately stood out from the moment I walked in,...
review_full: I was fortunate enough to be staying around the corner and it was the closest place. There are so many mediocre places to eat in Madrid, I was happy to have been this lucky. This place immediately stood out from the moment I walked in, being greeted by Abraham Garcia himself, as they proceeded to wow me, one course after another. Especially when I came in by myself, at close to midnight. The Gazpacho was incredible (which is tough for a cold soup) and things just got better from there. I don't spend much time on writing reviews, but this one deserved it - if you are ready for a great atmosphere and dining experience - this place gets my vote as best in Madrid.

review_preview: After having dined at Viridiana I am baffled as to why so many of the reviews are so positive. My partner and I dined there in late August the experience was mediocre and expensive. The food was good but not exceptional, and the service was...
review_full: After having dined at Viridiana I am baffled as to why so many of the reviews are so positive. My partner and I dined there in late August the experience was mediocre and expensive. The food was good but not exceptional, and the service was risible.  In our reservation, we had noted that one of us doesn't eat fish or fowl. The first waiter we had mentioned that the staff had seen this. The second waiter brought in a complementary starter that had fish in it. We politely pointed out that one of us doesn't eat fish, and the waiter took the plate away and brought a vegetarian alternative. Fine. But the second complementary starter, brought in after we had finished the first one, also contained fish. This was set down in front of the non-fish eater by the same waiter. We reminded him that one of us doesn't eat fish. He took the plate away and made himself scarce. After waiting 10 minutes for him return with something, we called the waiter over and asked him what was happening, would the non-fish eater be getting something else? "No", the waiter answered "it doesn't matter, the food you ordered will be coming in next".  We demurred that it did matter. He went off in a huff and came back with a small bowl of lentil soup. Again, good food, but should one really have to argue with a waiter to get it?  This continued. We ordered a bottle of wine with our dinner. Only about 5 minutes after the main courses had arrived did the waiter come over to inform us that the restaurant was out of the wine we had ordered. At this point we were irritated and told him that it would have been nice if he had thought to mention this before our food had arrived. The waiter brought us two glasses of wine on the house, but he made a show of this, like he was doing us a special favor.  All in all the experience was regrettable. Especially at a price tag of €130. Also, know this: if you book a table, like we did, at 20.30, you will be seated together downstairs with a few non-Spanish tourists. Other reviews of this restaurant mention this and one should take it seriously. It is not particularly pleasant sitting in a near-empty restaurant with other tourists. It feels like a charter trip to the Canary Islands.

title_review: There's a reason it's been around since 1830

review_full: You'll read in other reviews that the place is tiny, and it is. It seats 26 people in a very intimate setting. It's not design as a place where you seat in magnificent isolation to enjoy a fine and complex meal served by dozens of waiters. Rather, it's the Taperia at its best, with great little dishes, many of them original to El Mollete, that taste great. We went there once and our only regret is that we couldn't come back a second time.

review_preview: This restaurant was the closest from our excellent hotel (Petit Palace Savoy Alfonso XII).It was a Sunday afternoon, hard time to find open restaurant serving lunch in Spain.We got the recommendation from the reception of the hotel and were not disappointed! Not cheap...
review_full: This restaurant was the closest from our excellent hotel (Petit Palace Savoy Alfonso XII). It was a Sunday afternoon, hard time to find open restaurant serving lunch in Spain. We got the recommendation from the reception of the hotel and were not disappointed!  Not cheap at all, but definitely worth the money. Attentive and very polite staff. Our waiter gave us a deep explanation about the dishes. Premium food! Anchovies with white asparagus cream was a real delight (chef's treat). Foie gras + dessert wine - very good with beautiful serving(see photoes). Meat and fish dishes were of good quality and taste as well. At the end we've ordered desserts and got another dish from the chef - beautifully served plums in wine with delicious truffles at side. Also we had a bottle of Rioja. For the 6 people the bill came at 440 EU which is pretty expensive, but once again - worth the money!

title_review: Not as good as I remember
review_preview: Used to be a better restaurant but seems to have fallen sleep. The restaurant is kind of outdated in many ways - the décor could some call it cozy but for my taste is dark and uninviting. Service is so-so at best - it is...
review_full: Used to be a better restaurant but seems to have fallen sleep. The restaurant is kind of outdated in many ways - the décor could some call it cozy but for my taste is dark and uninviting. Service is so-so at best - it is the type of restaurant that probably due to its past success forgot to be pleasant to customers, bordering on being arrogant. Best example of both things was a customer sitting at a table that the air conditioner hit him right in the head, making it very uncomfortable. The vent was the old ones that cannot be redirected, so after several complaints from the customer they decided to shut down the whole A/C. So when we got hot (according to the waiter own thermometer), they would turn it on again, to be followed by some more complaining and off again. That was how we spent the night, on, off, on and so on. Funny thing was that there were other tables available but they were "reserved" by some people that even after we left never showed up. At the end you could put up with this is the food was amazing but it wasn't. Was good, no question about that, but nothing so good to write home about it. So, good food with so-so service in an outdated place is nothing to really be excited about in a city that has so many great alternatives.

We had among other things a completely tasteless Caprese with icey cold tomatoes and rubberlike mozarella. We also had a dish with potatoes and squid, a speciality cocked in the owen. Everything utterly tasteless, expensive in spite of the simple ingredients and, sorry to say, gave a sort of "fake" feeling. These dishes probably are specialities and they probably are delicious - at another restaurant! The place seemed to lack kitchen for hot food, hot food was brought from across the street. And I assure you, any real marketfood or streetfood will be much better than this!! I can not explaine the otherwise so very good reviews about this restaurant. But this was our true experience! Spend your money elsewhere! / Anna & family

review_preview: Arriving late in Madrid on a Friday evening we weren't sure where to go to eat.  Checked on Trip Advisor and made our way to El Mollete.  Very, very busy and very small.  However, one of the members of staff, moved some people out of...
review_full: Arriving late in Madrid on a Friday evening we weren't sure where to go to eat. Checked on Trip Advisor and made our way to El Mollete. Very, very busy and very small. However, one of the members of staff, moved some people out of the way and made room for us. We had an excellent meal of broken eggs, pork strips and goats cheese in pastry with honey. Best tapas ever. No one spoke English but we were made more than welcome. We went back again before we left we had been so delighted with the service. Even although when we went back the kitchen wasn't supposed to be open, we were served with chicken and the signature broken eggs dish with a lovely bottle of wine. Will definitely be back if we return to Madrid.

title_review: Good food and atmosphere - no frills
review_preview: We (two couples) ate here on a Saturday night in October 2014. We came at the recommendation of a friend who lives in Madrid. There was no table available when we showed up but the waiter said "10 minutes" so we stood at the bar...
review_full: We (two couples) ate here on a Saturday night in October 2014. We came at the recommendation of a friend who lives in Madrid. There was no table available when we showed up but the waiter said "10 minutes" so we stood at the bar and ordered a nice bottle of Ramon Bilbao Crianza Rioja. We were promptly served (including a small tapas of sausage) and after a few minutes our table was ready. We ordered the meat plate for two (€18) and the seafood plate for two (€33). Both were very good and served with plenty of salad and chips. The place itself is very atmospheric and is quite popular with locals which is good to see. Excellent value if not haute cuisine!

review_preview: This restaurant is fairly expensive, but it is definitely worth it. Now that I have got that out of my system, I can write about the food. The cooking is unmistakably traditional, although at a very high standard. If you expected liquid nitrogen and flavoured...
review_full: This restaurant is fairly expensive, but it is definitely worth it. Now that I have got that out of my system, I can write about the food.  The cooking is unmistakably traditional, although at a very high standard. If you expected liquid nitrogen and flavoured soil, then look elsewhere. Ironically, the cuisine appears at odds with the décor, which contains scenes from the 1961 film Viridiana and suggests a more playful and subversive vibe from a time slightly forgotten. However, the dishes are what I can describe only as the biased childhood memories of grandma’s cooking. Please do not read this in a bad way, the meals have a lovely smoky and rustic depth of flavour that is difficult to recreate. We had the game cannelloni and the veal as mains, and regretted nothing. The wine list is extensive, and very reasonable. We chose a lovely Ribera to accompany us. What really stood out was the experience of talking to the chef, Abraham. It is rare to start discussing Sashimi and to end with Kafka – but it reveals that there is more than meets the eye here.  Take a table upstairs - the decor is more interesting.

title_review: So good, we had to eat there two nights in a row!
review_preview: We were in Madrid for two nights and my boyfriend has a strict no-eating-at-the-same-place-twice rule BUT the food was so good, it didn't take much to convince him otherwise!FIRST NIGHT- Food - For tapas (appetizers), we ordered croquetas de jamon iberico and paella....
review_full: We were in Madrid for two nights and my boyfriend has a strict no-eating-at-the-same-place-twice rule BUT the food was so good, it didn't take much to convince him otherwise! FIRST NIGHT - Food -  For tapas (appetizers), we ordered croquetas de jamon iberico and paella. By the way, the paella was - hands down - the best paella I had in Spain. While on this trip, we visited five different cities and I made it a point to try paella in all of them but not one compared to Venta el Buscon's. As our main course, we ordered a seafood special for two (see picture). It included lobster tails and all kind of shrimp - DELICIOUS.  - Service -  The service was amazing. Manuel was our server for the night. We greeted us, treated us like regulars from the start and even gave us free drinks at the end of the night!  - Ambiance -  Venta El Buscon definitely has a bar/pub feel to it. Both nights it was crowded but the service felt far from rushed. We were able to enjoy our meal and conversation just fine.  SECOND NIGHT - Food -  For tapas, we ordered ham croquettes, paella (again, because delicious!) and chorizo. For our main course we ordered another special for two but this time all types of meat. Again, the good did not disappoint. - Service -  Here is when we got very annoyed. Manuel was so busy that night that he was another serve wait our table - Rodrigo. I was unsure whether Rodrigo was new on the job or just to the restaurant but he was quite rude. Listen, it is not every day you are in Spain (all the way from the States) so we ordered 3 tapas and 1 big main course. When we were about to order our main course, Rodrigo made a face and made the following off hand comment, "you're going to keep ordering? I think you've ordered enough for the night." This comment was rude on levels that I cannot even begin to explain. Simply put, it's our body, it's our MONEY so bring us all the food we order because we are going to PAY for it.  Rodrigo's comment was the only mishap during our two visits at Venta el Buscon. Still, I strongly recommend it because of the food and location. It's in the heart of the city and right across the street from a club called "Son" where they play Latin music to dance all night long.  Great find!

review_preview: We saw El Mollete recommended and thought we'd try it. We won't be going back. We ordered two tapas, Croquetas and Magre de pato. The croquetas arrived within five minutes along with two (rather small) glasses of tinto. Then nothing, not even a basket of...
review_full: We saw El Mollete recommended and thought we'd try it. We won't be going back. We ordered two tapas, Croquetas and Magre de pato. The croquetas arrived within five minutes along with two (rather small) glasses of tinto. Then nothing, not even a basket of bread, for another fifteen minutes. We finished the croquetas, and waited. Eventually the magre de pato turned up and they realised they had forgotten the bread, so then they brought that. The pato was good, which made things a little better. However, the service was rather poor, and at 10 euro each the tapas were expensive. It's a tiny place, with the servicios to be found upstairs by squeezing past a table of customers. There was no soap, no hand-drying facility and no lock on at least one of the two stalls. Overall, not a good experience, and I can't understand why there are so many favourable reviews.

review_preview: This was a recommendation from "36 Hours in Madrid by NY Times" and was very well worth it.  This is a small restaurant conviniently located next to Opera station. Make sure to reserve in advance.  They will not take a reservation if you are traveling...
review_full: This was a recommendation from "36 Hours in Madrid by NY Times" and was very well worth it. This is a small restaurant conviniently located next to Opera station. Make sure to reserve in advance. They will not take a reservation if you are traveling solo so your best bet just to walk in and get a seat on a bar table next to the wall (if you are lucky). Although the waiters don't speak English, they are very welcoming and attentive. Make sure to try their huevos rotos and cheese cake for dessert. They have good tapaz and wine selection. The total bill for two tapaz, entry, a glass of wine, and a dessert came to 30 Euros. I will definetely go back.

review_full: Not sure as to why there are the negative comments about this restaurant - this restaurant offers a fine dining experience of the highest quality and for which you will pay a premium, a premium for which I think is totally worth it. The menu is based around many traditional Spanish dishes and the quality of the food and cooking is at the highest of standards - it may not be to some peoples' taste but it certainly does not merit some of the negative comments on here, which should be generally ignored since thankfully the positive outweigh the negative ones. As a couple we paid 209 euros for aperitif (glass of Cava) starters, main, cheese course, 1/2 bottle of wine & a traditional Spanish digestive (Aquardiente) - which we believe is not bad value for what we ate. We will certainly be returning there for another visit when we return to Madrid !! I would also like to add that we both have very limited Spanish language skills and we found the waiting staff & chef very patient and attentive while dealing with us & accommodating for our 'SPANGLISH' -

review_preview: As many of us, before travelling to Madrid, I booked Viridiana well in advance because the reviews and rating were good, it is situated in the porshest area of Madrid surrounded by 5-star hotels. I didn't know the layout of the restaurant and didn't know...
review_full: As many of us, before travelling to Madrid, I booked Viridiana well in advance because the reviews and rating were good, it is situated in the porshest area of Madrid surrounded by 5-star hotels. I didn't know the layout of the restaurant and didn't know that the restaurant has a small room on the ground floor and a larger basement with no windows. My Spanish friends said they dined at this restaurant many years ago when they had just a ground floor and when Viridiana was a top one in Madrid. We were advised to follow the waitress down to the basement and when I queried whether we could stay on the ground floor, the answer was short and straightforward that I didn't book the table on the ground floor. One would expect the manager to tell you about that when you book a table, and if you don't ask you have no choice but to follow the instructions.  We were the first to sit at our table as soon as the restaurant opens for dinner at 8:30pm and I was wondering whether the basement fills in. And it did! But I noticed they were similar parties like ours - foreigners with their Spanish friends or just English speaking tourists. I made a conclusion that if you don't speak Spanish and you don't know where you want to sit, you have no option. One of the guidelines of a good restaurant is a state of their toilets and these were appalling. Toilets in McDonalds on Gran Via are in better conditions than these dating back probably to 1980s. Service was invasive and patronising as if we were in a paramount of an eating place. Chef in his traditional outfit marched up and down the basement about five times in two hours. I actually wondered who was cooking for us as he has time to spend so much time in the hall. Except bread the food was mediocre, a disgrace for famous Spanish chefs. And the bill for a party of three with a bottle of good but inexpensive Portuguese Reserva was short of £300. I don't understand why that place earned so many excellent point. Besides bread, I didn't find any. Tourists' trap mostly for those who want to step out of their 5-star hotels for a meal out.

title_review: Best way to celebrate our 3rd wedding anniversary
review_preview: we (the hubby and I) showed up without a reservation, we were welcomed in and the chef/owner told us it was fine,not to worry and he sent us downstairs where we sat in a corner table just for two..for me it was cozy enough for...
review_full: we (the hubby and I) showed up without a reservation, we were welcomed in and the chef/owner told us it was fine,not to worry and he sent us downstairs where we sat in a corner table just for two..for me it was cozy enough for both of us (I did not waste my time observing the "ambience" since the atmosphere is what you bring) anyhow the waiter inmediatly came to us and recommended us to try the Bellini (champagne with peach) it was delicious... then the chef/owner Abraham showed up and proceeded to narrarate between amusing quirks and funny jokes the menu "outside" the menu, which if you don´t speak spanish you might not get it but you can tell and see that he loves what he does and is very proud of it. I went ahead and tried the salad he had recommended and then proceeded to order the Grilled Beef tenderloin with Corn Blinis soft goat cheese melted and foie ..2 minutes later the waiter brought us complimentary Gazpacho with strawberry and red herring(to die for) and complimentary plate (each) of Iberic Ham, capers,dill pickle and tomatoe with (I think) an anchovy sauce.. I will say this by the time my plate showed up I was half full, the food was superb, the amount, the quality beyond excellent...since I still had space I requested the Ice cream and sorbet with brandy..once again the amount was enough for two (one was piña colada and the other was fig..the taste was slightly bland for my liking but nevertheless it was creamy) though my husband requested Chocolate Mousse with Greek Yogurt and fresh Raspberries and to finish it all they surprised us with a large amount of Dark chocolate truffles (like 10) and coconut cookies (6)also complimentary.All this cost us aprox 170 euros (including the glass of red wine ribera del duelo we requested) which is not bad for fine cuisine.

review_preview: I struggle to imagine how anyone could rate the food and service at Viridiana anything less than excellent! No, it's not the kind of food that you would find in midwest America, but that's the point! It's unique; it's creative; but incredibly delicious and satisfying....
review_full: I struggle to imagine how anyone could rate the food and service at Viridiana anything less than excellent! No, it's not the kind of food that you would find in midwest America, but that's the point! It's unique; it's creative; but incredibly delicious and satisfying. The Gazpacho is utterly amazing and since tomatoes are a fruit, it's not such a stretch to add another fruit to it. So as not to fill up before my main arrived, I had to push back from the delicious bread with its crispy crust and soft center! The seafood salad is outstanding, not inexpensive at around 12 Euros, but it's chocked full of grilled scallops, shrimp and baby squid! Our meal was one we will not soon forget!

review_preview: We enjoyed our dinner at Viridiana. We were greeted at the door and led to our table by a friendly waiter. Before receiving our salad, we had the complimentary strawberry/seafood gazpacho. Contrary to another reviewer, we loved the soup, (however a small bowl is just...
review_full: We enjoyed our dinner at Viridiana. We were greeted at the door and led to our table by a friendly waiter. Before receiving our salad, we had the complimentary strawberry/seafood gazpacho. Contrary to another reviewer, we loved the soup, (however a small bowl is just enough). We also had the complementary Iberian ham and melon. The salad we shared and was plated for two people was a nopal (cactus) salad with tomato, anchovies, and zested orange. We loved it. My husband had the guinea fowl with a plum sauce and I had pork meat balls in a curry sauce with roasted peach slices. Both entrees were delicious. We topped it off with a great bottle of wine and mango and passion fruit for dessert. The chef came out and spoke to many of the patrons, however, I do not think he spoke English and therefore, he just motioned a "hello" to us and asked if everything was good. I would recommend this restaurant if you want good local flavors, a small, intimate setting, and good service.

review_preview: We went for dinner last night and were sent there on the recommendation of a very famous Spanish chef. We began with the gazpacho, a dish I grew up with and loved, they added chunks of strawberries and herring to it! I get the sweet...
review_full: We went for dinner last night and were sent there on the recommendation of a very famous Spanish chef. We began with the gazpacho, a dish I grew up with and loved, they added chunks of strawberries and herring to it! I get the sweet and salty thing but this did not work. The bites I had of the soup with out the fish/fruit combo were delicious, to bad. It was served alongside so Ibirco ham and melon, which were delicious. Then we had the egg with mushroom sauce and truffles this was a great dish. I can't complain about it. I ordered the leg of lamb with couscous. The lamb was great, tender with a crunchy skin, the couscous was a dry afterthought. My husband had the steak that he enjoyed, huge and well cooked. The place is poorly decorated with a Hollywood movie theme. It looked like something out of the '80s. But the worst part is that we were both sick in the middle of the night and the next morning. The service was good.

We were about to order one more dish to share when our waiter recommended the cheesecake and fondant for desert, wow, what a delicious finish... Atmosphere was great, nice cosy tables, very friendly helpful staff and our bill only came to 53euro including 4 soft drinks for a very substantial meal, by far the best meal we've eaten in madrid...  I would recommend you book or arrive early (before 9pm) to avoid getting turned away as we did a couple of nights before, and listen to the waiters suggestions as they were spot on....

review_preview: On a city break to Madrid, looking at the guide book, it mentioned Viridiana -  larger-than-life chef, one of the best restaurants in Madrid. I assumed that it would be impossible to get a table, but no - the answer is to go early, 8.30...
review_full: On a city break to Madrid, looking at the guide book, it mentioned Viridiana - larger-than-life chef, one of the best restaurants in Madrid. I assumed that it would be impossible to get a table, but no - the answer is to go early, 8.30 usually does it - and we were not disappointed!  The meal was wonderful, the surroundings very interesting, the staff incredibly friendly and accommodating and the bill very resonable considering the generosity of the chef and the excellent standard of the food - and wine!  I would definitely eat there again and would heartily recommend it to anyone visiting Madrid.

review_preview: This place is not expensive. Let me explain. It's all relative. This place is expensive compared to a tapas bar in Madrid, that's true, but that's not what this is.  Abraham Garcia, the chef, has written at least three books. His kitchen has seen the...
review_full: This place is not expensive. Let me explain. It's all relative. This place is expensive compared to a tapas bar in Madrid, that's true, but that's not what this is. Abraham Garcia, the chef, has written at least three books. His kitchen has seen the likes of David Munoz (currently 3 star michelin holder in Madrid) and Ramon Freixa (2 star michelin) apprentice there and he continues to be inventive while retaining the flavors of his native Galicia. I will admit that if you don't speak Spanish you will miss out on his "explanation" of the day's specials and that is really something (even this native Spanish speaker had a hard time keeping up). But forget about all that and just enjoy the dishes. Other reviewers claim that the "amuse buche" and appetizers eclipsed the main course and I must sadly agree but there were two amuse buche and two appetizers so I guess four out of five is not bad. Highlights include the eggs with truffles, the deer and the sweetbreads. You have to search the wine menu for value because I did find the wine list expensive. I ended up with a Jumilla for $45E which is the most I paid for a bottle of wine in Spain. All told, for 4 people, after two amuse buche a piece, two appetizers for the table, four entrees, two glasses of cava to start, a bottle of wine and dessert (plus petit fours) the bill came to $307E, not cheap but less than half of what one would pay for a similar restaurant in the States.

title_review: An iconic establishment for clear reasons
review_preview: A friend from Madrid suggested this restaurant if we were carrying around some extra cash. Yes, it is quite expensive. More so than places we normally go, though we do indulge once in awhile.I think people will fall into two camps on Viridiana. Some...
review_full: A friend from Madrid suggested this restaurant if we were carrying around some extra cash. Yes, it is quite expensive. More so than places we normally go, though we do indulge once in awhile. I think people will fall into two camps on Viridiana. Some will think that the menu is brilliantly creative, while others will find it a bit fussy. We tend to fall towards the latter. That said, the cooking itself is unquestionably top notch. Further, the service was absolutely flawless with a couple of exceptions early on when the head waiter, one of the finest waiters we have encountered in many a year, got pulled away to do seatings while in the middle of taking an order. The rest of the service staff was equally as professional, though not necessarily as genial as the head. Customers receive two dishes on the house: a parsnip soup with potatoes and ham, which was perfect in texture and taste, as well as a white pork with various side ingredients. The pork was an interesting concept, and the pickled cucumber was heavenly, but it seemed like a lot of effort for a fairly insignificant side dish. The 6 mushroom risotto was out of this world. One of the top 2 or 3 we have ever had. Plain and simple. A chick pea tortilla filled with Ropa Vieja was a very interesting concept, but very large portion coming on the heels of the house dishes and risotto. The tortilla itself was very light, and the Ropa Vieja avoided a lot of the extreme spicing or over-preparation one often finds in the dish. An accompanying baked apple was a nice though some what incongruous complement, but the cactus seemed a bit extraneous. A chocolate panacotta with berries was a perfect way to round out a very satisfying, though at times slightly precious, meal. Still, the best meal we had on our trip to Spain and very highly recommended if you have "extra cash" and can negotiate some of the culinary whims of the otherwise top chef kitchen.

title_review: Hard to find but well worth the hunt
review_preview: We had a night away from our tour group so walked to this restaurant from our hotel. It was hard to find but worth the bother. It is small and cozy and they are not fluent in English but it was not a problem. We...
review_full: We had a night away from our tour group so walked to this restaurant from our hotel. It was hard to find but worth the bother. It is small and cozy and they are not fluent in English but it was not a problem. We were made to feel so welcome with complimentary Gazpacho with red herring Unbelievable flavour. Each course for the three of us kept getting better, we ate far more that usual but were not sorry. The house wine was more than acceptable. I only wish I could return to this restaurant without having to fly to Spain. I am shocked to read some of the other reviews we all consider ourselves foodies and loved this one.

review_preview: Small, intimate, beautiful restaurant where the chef roams around to greet guests and introduce specials of the day.  There were 5 of us in the group and for the most part we enjoyed our meals.    Expect a more classic cuisine that is unpretentious.  It evokes...
review_full: Small, intimate, beautiful restaurant where the chef roams around to greet guests and introduce specials of the day. There were 5 of us in the group and for the most part we enjoyed our meals. Expect a more classic cuisine that is unpretentious. It evokes elevated homecooking, which is not a bad thing. Don't expect liquid nitrogen, foams, and molecular gastronomy. This is not the restaurant's mission. They give you an amuse bouche and an appetizer for starters--to our surprise. The servings were quite generous so they filled me up. By the time my shrimp fideo appetizer arrived, I was on the verge of fullness. I did not get to finish it because the serving was also quite generous. The fideo was disappointing, quite on the salty side, and unexciting (I had better). Next came my squid dish in black ink with green jasmine rice and vegetable concasse on the side. The dish was simple, but it delivered.  My colleagues loved their food - guinea fowl with the most delicious mole (I had a taste); a beef dish with vegetables (simple but rich in flavor). We didn't order dessert as we were beyond full. However, you will be rewarded with coconut macaroon balls and melt-in-your-mouth dark chocolate truffles for petit fours.

review_preview: Why did we waste one of our 5 dinners in Madrid on this place? Because I thought after reading the reviews that maybe it was people in the midwest that weren't used to cutting edge food and didn't appreciate it. I was so wrong. This...
review_full: Why did we waste one of our 5 dinners in Madrid on this place? Because I thought after reading the reviews that maybe it was people in the midwest that weren't used to cutting edge food and didn't appreciate it. I was so wrong. This is the type of restaurant that your grandparents would love, thinking that they were really cool for finding it. Because you know, things served on chargers and plate covers taken of with a flourish in front of you make up for the food. The food is average at best and for a price tag of about 200 Euros for a bottle of wine, 2 appetizers and 2 entrees, I expected better and I'm fine with paying that if I get something quality and interesting. We had a far superior meal at La Vega Del Arte for only 60 Euros and couldn't believe the flavors there. We enjoyed the amuse bouches at Viridiana much more than the actual apps and entrees that we ordered. The gazpacho with the fish and fruit was actually interesting and tasty (but this was an amuse not a menu item). This place is about presentation, the interior was well decorated, the food was plated attractively and the service was attentive. The flavors and price tag? not worth it.

review_preview: This is a place to go in a special occasion. The tables are very close, the restaurant is very small and you can enjoy the beautiful dishes others are eating.The service is very good and attentive, the food is presented in such an original...
review_full: This is a place to go in a special occasion. The tables are very close, the restaurant is very small and you can enjoy the beautiful dishes others are eating. The service is very good and attentive, the food is presented in such an original way that you are already enjoying it while it is bring to your table and you are tempted to take pictures or steer at it forever. Then you eat it and another dimension of happiness and pleasure kicks in as you enjoy the flavors.  If you go during Christmas time, order the "Helado de Roscón de Reyes". Indeed the best ice cream I ever ate.
